Have you ever thought to yourself "If I were in Hitlers shoes, I would have done much better."?

Well, now is your chance to put your money where your mouth is!

Just like Hitler, you'll have a bunch of assholes working for you that don't do shit!
Just like Hitler, this war will make you want to do copious amounts of drugs!
Just like Hitler, you'll want to shoot yourself in the head by the end because no matter how much you prepare, no matter how advanced you get, no matter how much political power you have... one little mistake will lead to a crushing defeat.

Let me explain this game in a different way...
Build up your excitement.
Get overwhelmed by the learning curve.
Have a couple seizures as you watch the night and day sequence flash by over and over again.
Lose your fucking mind over all the tiny numbers and symbols and shapes that all move around at the speed of light, only to vaguely see through the numerical chaos that you are slowly losing ground to a bunch of Bolsheviks.
Realize you've spent more than two hours trying to understand this crap rendering it too late for a refund.
Spend another two hours trying to understand the damn shitty tutorial.
Spend another hour watching a YouTube video of some overly enthusiastic assclown explain how to play the game.
Try it all again and spend hours building up infrastructure, armies, navies, airforces, defenses, tanks, factories, naval yards, radios, to have it all fall to some shitty little country with cavalry units!!!!
WTF!?!?!

Let me explain this game yet another way...
Not worth it.
Remove from Wishlist.
Uninstall. 
Never look back.

This is probably the second best paradox game after EU4, but absolutely the best if you are a new player to Paradox GSG. HOI4 allows for a more simple political system than any other game, but maximized the level of combat detail and manufacturing variety. Tanks, Planes, Ships, Etc. are all very unique depending on how you design them. 10/10 for anyone who enjoys history and/or games with a  very complex but rewarding management system.

Seriously a game I love to hate but keep coming back to time and time again like an abusive relationship, just to keep finding the same infuriating gameplay "features" and half baked additions thru overpriced required DLC packs. 

The buildup before the war is fun if you enjoy setting up your forces and managing the construction/research aspect, but once the war starts the engines deficiencies become apparent and no amount of modding can fix it. Factions remain completely useless and if anything a hindrance. Been asking for years a better faction command system to allow for a SHAEF-type of unified command structure to make a combined/joint force with the player in command. Instead one the war start be prepared for you 'allies' just doing whatever they want and acting is if you were just another neutral and spamming random areas with their divisions.

Honestly the only reason to play this game is because of the mod community since PDX keeps pumping out underdeveloped features in DLC packs that cost way too much, and often include things that the wonderful mod community has already done but better. Only purchase when the product and DLC is discounted.

This will be a very very long review, so real quick recap of what I'm yapping about: I've played a lot of Hearts of Iron IV, and in general I recommend the game because I love the modding community, the numerous options for alternative history, and the beautiful art that makes the game look so nice. But I recognize that the game has its issues, especially relating to the toxicity and radical political ideas in the community, stupidity of the AI, the large number of bugs and glitches, and an insufficient balance between complexity or simplicity depending on the game mechanic. There will be another quick recap at the end too by the way.

Hearts of Iron IV is a grand strategy game focused around the devastating global conflict colloquially referred to as World War 2. The game features a very detailed and well thought out game based on the history of the time period, but also leaves room for modifications of history, perhaps to the advantage of the country of your choosing. The game features many things, among which it has modding support.

The modding community is fantastic, and although the capabilities provided by the developers to create mods aren't particularly spectacular, modders can do very cool things with such limitations regardless. The mods the community has made can be anything ranging from simple patches for bugs, fixes or clarification of a tooltip or other feature that the developers overlooked, adding a new cool idea to the game, or outright transforming the game into something totally different. Total overhaul mods are amazing, some already exist to bring players back to World War 1 in the Great War mod, or into the modern age with a mod like Millennium Dawn.

The content already provided in-game is fantastic, some admittedly being a bit outlandish, but that's to be expected of a historical sandbox simulator. The number of opportunities for alternative history is crazy, and more options keep arising as the developers release more DLCs (as of now the next DLC "Trials of Allegiance" is due to release soon). The major countries already have diverse content and alternative history options, but many minor nations that played a key role in World War 2 also have paths too (but not all minor nations; South America lacks content entirely. though Trials of Allegiance will fix that soon).

Also, something not mentioned much with Hearts of Iron, but I absolutely LOVE the art, the focus icons, the technologies, the loading screens, and UI, it's all so good. Not to mention the 3D models of soldiers, trucks, artillery, planes, ships, etc. I've gotta give credit where it's due to the developers who made such a beautiful looking game.

As of now, Hearts of Iron IV is easily one of the best grand strategy games focused on World War 2 that money can buy currently. Admittedly this is a bit of a double edged sword, because the game is not perfect (which I'll get into soon) and as such is clearly not at its best. It's in fact one of the only World War 2 grand strategy games, making it really the only choice; that's not great. Now, I feel it important to talk about because I find personally that there are some issues with Hearts of Iron IV

For starters, let's talk about the overall community (outside of modding for the most part). It's a mess. Simply put, if you aren't a particularly competitive individual, there's not much fun to be had in multiplayer. The toxicity to be found in the Hearts of Iron IV community is appalling, let alone the very radical political ideas you'll hear (either ironically or unironically). If you want an experience with Hearts of Iron IV that isn't super toxic, I would avoid the community in many cases (sometimes it can be quite nice; especially with people you know, but be careful otherwise).

The game itself isn't too bad, at least not compared to the community. However there is some shortcomings, particularly around the areas of the stupidity of the AI, the number of weird bugs and glitches, and the lag. Oh god the lag. Late game is rough for lower end to middle end PCs, because the game is weirdly unoptimized for dealing with the massive spam of equipment, divisions, and really anything by AI (including nukes after some time). AI is pretty stupid; not much to elaborate on there. There's lots of weird bugs to be had with all of the alternative history paths the game offers, sometimes the developers overlook something an accidentally leave a loophole to be abused.

Depending on who you ask, Hearts of Iron IV might be either too complex or too simple, and personally I think both could be true to an extent. It's true that Hearts of Iron IV did not even release with a espionage system in place; a very important factor in World War 2, instead the developers would release a paid DLC to add that feature into the game. Hearts of Iron IV faces massive simplification in certain areas from its predecessor: Hearts of Iron III, notably the simplification of the weather system. Some have argued Hearts of Iron IV is too complex, I mean, look at the naval systems, it's a huge meme in the community to not know how the navy works despite thousands of hours.

Both sentiments are right to an extent, certain things about the game have been simplified far too much, and other systems are far too complicated to be fully understood by even long time players sometimes. A balance needs to be struck, or otherwise giving players the options to a more simplified or complex system for most systems could be ideal (even if that increases the development time, I'd say it would be worthwhile). The same could be applied to modding, it would be nice to have far more powerful modding capabilities, but I understand why one might want a custom language dedicated to modding the game. Perhaps a choice could be made to accept both forms, I don't know how it would work but it would be nice to have such.

There's a lot more to be said about this game, both good and bad, but I feel that this review is long enough as is, and I've yapped enough as is. As stated earlier in my TL:DR, Hearts of Iron IV is one of the best games out there, which offers a wonderful modding community, great alternate history options, and beautiful art, yet has some problems including stupid AI, plenty of bugs and glitches, poor optimization, and hasn't struck the best balance between complexity and simplicity. Overall I enjoy the game and would recommend you try it out if you're willing to pay a bunch of money for DLC and the base game that's actively improving over time; if not, I totally understand.

Easily one of the best WW2 Simulators out there. I don't comment on games often, and I know my amount of hours may not convince you but I promise it's worth it. One thing I will say, as a negative, is that the DLC policy can be...sketch, in that you have to pay for about $20 at least for most of the important DLC. However, during sales that paradox does often you can get them in packs for a decent price overall. Sucks to have to wait for them, but is what it is. Another is that, as is common for most paradox games, the multiplayer while very much alive. has problems with disconnects often. Its not impossible to play, but expect at least one desync per MP game. Although you can simply reload a save, which is autosaves often. I believe you can even change how many times it does and when. Gameplay-wise I would advise you watch videos of it on youtube to see if its your type of game. I can say I love the game to death, but that means jack to you. Anyway, 10/10 game I'd def say try it. There are more comments that give better info I'm sure.

So I have put some extensive time into this game and to be quite honest I can't recommend mainly due to paradoxes sheer greed with their predatory DLC system they have in place. The core game itself is fun when you get the hang of things I wont deny that and the modding community definitely has helped keep this game alive with some of its content. My main issue is the DLC's that are dropped for 20$ every time and add very little to the overall game play that modders have already done a better job than paradox. Even when the DLC's are on sale they're still not worth it, they add little to nothing and this content is basically a piece meal system to draw players back in to only be bored in about 2 weeks max after playing the "new" content. Paradox is greedy as hell and for the base game without being on sale to be 40$ for then one DLC to be half the cost of the main game is fucking repugnant. If you want a fun strategy game the base game is good for that for a little while but only get it on sale, as far as the DLC's go they aren't worth your time or money to be quite honest, half the time they end up breaking the game more often than not.

i have tried playing this game for many years and while I do love in it some way, I have not had a single successful game. In terms of gameplay and accessibility, I honestly think this is the worst paradox game. Which is a shame because aside from that, this game is quite amazing especially with mods.

Most paradox games you can figure out where you are going wrong, why you failed this one time around, or learning a new mechanic through your failures. Not HOI4 though. Do not expect to win even a single war following the online guides, tutorials, and meta builds for armies and supply. 

I honestly strongly recommend not even buying this game even if you think you can learn through other players online. The community for this game in my experience has been straight up toxic and full of keyboard warrior douchebags who instead of helping you online will instead only frustrate you more than however many hours you have just sunk into a playthrough just to lose immediately.

The dev team also seems to just make more mechanics every update. While this improves the experience for regular players, it just completely resets the task of figuring out how to play for players like me who are still trying to figure out how tf to play.

I've come back to revise my review again after another 2,500 or so hours, as my opinion has drastically changed to the point that it is no longer covered by a short joke review.

I have played this game for over 3,500 hours. I love playing this game. I don't regret the money I have spent on it. I will continue playing this game well into the future.
With all of this in mind, I would absolutely NOT recommend you buy this game (or more specifically any of its DLC) unless you are at least 90% certain you will love it. It takes at least a thousand hours to learn the game. It costs over a hundred dollars to get the full game experience from heavily overpriced DLC, most of which aren't good enough to justify not just going without. It's riddled with old bugs that have gone unpatched and will likely remain for quite some time. Official paid content is regularly outranked by community-created workshop content.
Do not get me wrong, I do not at all wish to discourage someone who may genuinely be interested in this genre, this is a fantastic game if you want to play it. HOWEVER, if you have even the slightest doubt or are unwilling to invest the time required to learn the game and make the cost worth it, I would not recommend purchasing this game.

This is not (necessarily) a critique of the game, this is meant to be my advice for people looking to buy the game.

TL;DR:
Wait until it goes on sale before buying, and only if you really want to play it. Feel free to use community content if you don't want to play with DLC.

I want to make a very short and concise review of Hearts of Iron IV. 
Pros:
It is a very addicting, very fun strategy game that involves the map changing colors. 
One of the biggest modded communities next to Gmod and Black Ops III. 
Plenty of content to sink your teeth into (with many more on the way)
Relatively healthy community

Cons:
It is a massive learning curve. You will need to invest time and energy into playing, watching, researching and asking questions about this game. I recommend iSorrowsProductions and r/hoi4 for content
Long game (4+ hours a run)
It becomes very slow in late game hoi4, past 1945 the game gets bogged down by the AI and all its useless units.


Overall: I think this game is for anyone looking for something fresh to learn and has a passion for history

As someone who has spent countless hours delving into the intricate world of grand strategy games, I must say that Hearts of Iron IV falls woefully short of expectations. To put it bluntly, this game is about as challenging as tying your shoelaces, and it requires about as much skill as making a peanut butter and jelly sandwich. In fact, I'd go so far as to say that recommending this game to anyone with an education level beyond the second grade is an insult to their intelligence.

Let's start with the so-called "difficulty" of Hearts of Iron IV. From the moment you boot up the game, it's painfully apparent that the AI is about as threatening as a newborn kitten. Whether you're playing as a major power like Germany or a minnow like Luxembourg, you'll quickly find that the AI opponents are about as strategic as a goldfish swimming in circles. They lack any semblance of tactical nuance, making the game feel more like a glorified game of whack-a-mole than a true test of skill.

And don't even get me started on the learning curve‚Äîor lack thereof. Unlike other grand strategy games that reward careful planning and strategic foresight, Hearts of Iron IV practically holds your hand every step of the way. The user interface is so dumbed down that even a toddler could navigate it with ease, and the mechanics are about as deep as a puddle after a light rain. There's none of the depth or complexity that you'd expect from a game in this genre, leaving you feeling more like you're playing a game of Risk than commanding a nation during one of the most tumultuous periods in human history.

But perhaps the most egregious sin of Hearts of Iron IV is its utter lack of consequence. Whether you're conquering Europe as Hitler or fending off the Axis powers as Churchill, the outcomes feel about as impactful as a butterfly flapping its wings halfway across the world. There's no sense of weight or consequence to your actions, making it impossible to become truly invested in the outcome of your campaign. It's like playing a game of chess where every piece is made of marshmallow‚Äîsure, it might be fun for a little while, but it ultimately leaves you feeling empty and unfulfilled.

In conclusion, Hearts of Iron IV is a game that's about as challenging as breathing and about as fulfilling as eating a stale cracker. Its lack of depth, challenge, and consequence make it a poor choice for anyone looking for a true grand strategy experience. Unless you're a second grader‚Äîor perhaps someone with the intellectual curiosity of a second grader‚ÄîI'd recommend giving this one a hard pass. There are far better games out there that actually require you to use your brain.

The game is pretty boring after a few runs, as historical mode is exactly that, and trying to change that, the ai will still do exactly the historical things even though the whole world would be different. Non-historical mode is just madness, it just doesn't make any sense.

The DLCs are expensive and bring game essential features that are just pay walled. So basically buying the game is buying a trial version.

The modding community is a big reason to have this game. Many enthusiastic nice developers out there, on their free time making some amazing experiences. Yet the overall community is mostly toxic, cringe and many of them are extremists, which is quite interesting and fun.

It is quite clear that game developers don't care. Updates are few and far between, very little content and always introducing new bugs.

Now let's say hypothetically you wanted to play a mod with a friend. You would need to make sure you both subscribe to the same mod on workshop, usually few days or week earlier because some times it doesn't get downloaded. You need to check for updates, because your friend might have a newer version. Verify your game files as you might have some missing file or corrupt file for some reason. Maybe the mod file wasn't downloaded the file is empty or the pointer to the file in the documents folder is broken. Some times, even when you have checked everything, it just still doesn't work, check out Victoria 3 for that, can't play 2 or more mods in multiplayer. And then make sure you both play the same version as in not nakama, because nakama introduces more problems like Network Address Translation, and some times it doesn't but the normal version does. So some people can't join eachother, or maybe just the other.
If you are setting up a new mod, it usually takes another 2 hours before you get into the game. And usually 30 minutes to 2 hours until the game desyncs or crashes.

Paradox is just the definition of a shit poster but as a Publisher and Development company, as literally all of their modern titles are like this.

I enjoyed the detailed simulation of the practicalities of WW2. My personal favourite mechanic is the trains. Your logistics network is an important part of your war machine and you can gain an advantage by cutting your opponent's supply lines. I also recommend the Equestria At War mod if you know the my little pony franchise.
The Games alright

Yes, it takes a few game restarts to learn mechanics. However, its not frustrating. In my opinion it is very important to watch a youtube tutorial about basics before starting the first game. That said, game has its complexity covered with tooltips.

What I (and very few others) have found frustrating and kind of stubbornly stupid is that in this complex game we do not have an option in options to disable mouse panning. UI buttons are naturally at screen borders and any overshoot of cursor pans the camera away from what you are working on. Should be a simple thing to code that OPTION in. Was literally about to give up playing for this, but then I found a free cursor locking software "Lock Cursor Tools" and run it in background.

Also strange is that there is no key re-bind options. Can live with that tho...

A very public complain is that the game has many small, but interesting DLC:s, which cost 20‚Ç¨ each. So basically you buy the base game as a demo/stripped trial version and for the whole game you will end up paying over 100‚Ç¨. And its worth it in my opinion...

Hearts of Iron 4 isn't just a strategy game, it's a time machine to the deadliest conflict in history. Lead any nation through World War 2, forge alliances, wage epic land and air battles, and rewrite history. While initially daunting, the core gameplay loop of managing industry, research, and warfare is surprisingly accessible. But the depth is undeniable. Customize divisions, plan intricate offensives, and navigate a complex web of diplomacy. Each playthrough feels unique, offering endless replayability. Sure, the learning curve is steep, and some DLC feels essential, but for WW2 buffs and strategy aficionados, Hearts of Iron 4 is a masterpiece. Witness the rise and fall of nations, command millions to victory, and experience the thrill (and horror) of total war.

I don't think I'll ever get tired of this game. For such a confined time period there seems to be infinite replayablility. 

The learning curve is one of the steepest I've experienced, with me having over 600 hours, I still don't know all the aspects of the game and am just mediocre. However, behind the game is a passionate development team and even more expansive player base which all know your struggles and are more than willing to help you with your quests. 

This game is a history buff's wet dream as so many, even lucrative and not well known, paths exist for each country. Hell, even the achievements list has some of the silliest puns to serve as guides to play such as: "Australia-Hungary" and "Danzig Queen." 

TLDR: If you don't have this game, fix yourself and join the pain train!

This is a review of how Steam and Paradox treated one of their clients.

I subscribed to HOI4 in January 2022. Since then, I have been paying $6.55 CAD every lunar month.

Recently, Steam/Paradox increased the price of my subscription to $10.99 CAD.

I argued against the legality of such a price increase. To no avail.

Since both the platform and the producer of the game gave me the cold shoulder, I decided to cancel my HOI4 subscription.

Easier said than done. Why? Easy. Because the In Store Manage my Subscriptions button is not working.

I tried everything. Nothing works.

I contacted Steam. Again, they gave me the cold shoulder.

I am putting Steam on notice that I will be seeking legal redress if this abhorrent behaviour continues.

In any case, I removed my VISA information from the account and am letting Steam know that they must cancel my HOI4 subscription or face the legal consequences.

Short version:
Game is a unique experience in every sense of the word.

Long version:
- Get the game.

- You may agree with the game direction or not, but I challenge you to find a game as complex and interesting as this one.  In the meanwhile, this is as good as it gets if WW2 is your thing.

- As a personal anecdote, a few months back I got mad at the people at Paradox and Steam for censoring me a comment about enjoying HOI IV on weed and the moderator who f*** up never shown his/her face after that mess, but I gotta grant the forums and the game itself are not entirely related (business model).  Went to the Paradox website, opened a ticket and then it hit me how the gaming industry totally lost touch with their customers.   Whoever took my ticket (Andy I think was the last one), was very nice and understanding, yet, issue was never resolved and I did get censored without a mature explanation from anybody.  Steam is final on their decisions even so that means not giving a simple mature answer to their customers.  75% of PC market gives you that right, I suppose.  We're nothing.  Millions is the key, dollars and players.  Nothing really matters anymore for those who come from the classical golden eras of PC gaming where developers and people behind the distribution actually cared.

- Even so, as a personal desire, I'd love to see Paradox take care better care of their community, with a good start at having some serious, real moderation at the game's Steam forums.   *A lot* of caustic people there (including moderators) and it's sad to see how fast topics derail and go absolutely offtopic in a jiffy, yet you get punished for being merry and friendly.  You'll see/experiment lots of personal attacks, xenophobism (if live outside the "first world", be warned when participating), racism and wildly offtopic comments fill a forum that could be genuinely a place to gather information rather than pick a fight. 

- Get all the DLC (I'd skip the sabaton soundtracks, just a personal opinion), every DLC is worth it and game is not expensive really. There's a lot of work put in there and you can tell, even so in the little details; game graphics are out of this world and give HOI IV it's very unique style and feeling.  Soundtrack selection is wild, with speeches and music from all sides and kinds in a playlist that feels endlessly awesome.  

- If you get bored or want to expand the experience, the mods for the game are very well done, with a lot of effort and care put into.  Give yourself a treat, install a cheatmod and rule the world like you really meant to rewrite the history of the world. 

That's all folks.

To all of the obssesed hoi4 fans, I still think hoi4 is a great game but it's just not for me. If you're someone who wants to play a game with exciting and fun fast paced content this game is absolutely not for you. Hoi4 in my opinion is a slow boring and tedious game that will often make you frustrated and uninterested. The slow pace of the game makes it a snails walk to beat every single goal in the game, and it takes 30 minutes into the game to have anything really happen. If the game were cheaper I would still be recommending it, but 40 dollars is completely outrageous. I'm a person who wants to feel like their money is well spent, and when I played this game I was immediately dissapointed. Hoi4 is also very unbeginner-friendly, making me have to look up how to do something as simple as move soldiers to other areas in the middle of battle. 

In conclusion, if you are and old man or some person who has trouble keeping up the pace with other games then this is a perfect game for you. If you are someone who likes games that are fast paced, non-complex, and simple in & out then this game is absolutely not for you. 

If I offended any die-hard hoi4 fans you can go cry about it to your parents.

Hearts of iron 4 is a good if not a great game with mods, the mods add so much to the game.
if it's on sale and you like Grand strategy games Buy it i recommend it absolutely a easy 7.5/10 with no mods a 9/10 with mods

The main reason my review is a negative is the dlcs.
I'll keep it brief.
1: their pricey for what they have in them.
2: They have updated/new and balanced focus trees for countries that are in base game (Wouldn't be as big of a problem if they were all in 1 or 2 dlcs or just updates to the game)
3: Most of the dlcs add a new small game mechanic, examples man the guns adds ship designer no step back adds tank designer By blood alone adds planes designer and arms against tyranny adds a market that you can sell you're customised tanks planes and other equipment you see the problem? all of these should be in one dlc with another thing here or there for $10 to $20

And i guess that's my biggest problem, a lot of the small mechanics and small changes the dlcs have, should all be in 2 to 3 dlcs for $20 to $25 or just updates to the game.

Edit
One more thing the dlcs the add models for planes and tanks and the Other dlcs the have models for infantry for some countries should be free or all in one dlc for $5 Maximum, $3 realistically.

Having dlcs that have or add models to a game is no different to micro transactions.

To Paradox
You need to fix your dlcs

stop making so many dlcs that have little in them and cost too much, make big dlcs that have lots in them for $15 to $20.

stop making dlcs that make countries that are already in the game playable

Paradox is making normal updates that a game gets and holds onto them and puts them in a DLC with a random thing here or there and charges you $20+ and says "Here's a overpriced clearly ripped content and some community suggested changes, and balancing to the specific countries that are in is dlc, and yes it makes them stronger then the other counties that aren't in the dlc, so if you want your specific country to be updated buy this other dlc for $20+ and 
it also has clearly ripped content community suggested changes, and balancing."

And one last thing The dlcs that update certain countries make those countries stronger and funner compared to the countries that have no dlc or have a older dlc.

This game has got me all tied up in it and I cannot seem to find myself playing any other Steam Game (willingly). It has a very addicting base game and you don't even need to chase achievements or grind to have fun. Although the UI is difficult to learn at first, even I'm still discovering new parts about it, the UI is very manageable once you play once or twice. The Tutorial isn't the greatest however, and it hardly taught me anything. My recommendation is to watch a video instead.

Mods are another very important aspect of HOI4. I myself have been playing End of a New Beginning, Road to '56, and dabbled in FemBavaria. Mods can be an exciting escape from the base game but are really not needed to have fun. Neither are DLCs. In my unprofessional but educated and personal opinion, I rate Hearts of Iron IV a good 8.9/10

Very few other games really scratch the itch for global grand strategy like the Hearts of Iron series, and I find myself coming back to it regularly. Nevertheless, I leave each time greatly disappointed that issues that have been present from the beginning have not only not been fixed but have been exacerbated with each update. The AI, which already struggled from the game's inception, is now bogged down with dozens more features that it cannot manage effectively. Coherent strategic decision-making is absent, as is any semblance of threat assessment.

There is only so much enjoyment I can get out of a game where the AI makes repeated and obviously suicidal naval invasions, sends units unescorted halfway around the world to be sniped by convoy raiders for no clear purpose, and NEVER builds a single capital ship to threaten my fleet. This is besides the fact that the naval system manages to be both micro-intensive and too abstract, feeling clunky and nonintuitive even when compared to older titles like HoI3. The plethora of different stats and components do not clearly map on to how the units handle on the game map, and all of these efforts fail to make the essence of the game's naval combat anything other than smashing two rocks together until one of them breaks.

The frontline system has always been and continues to be miserably frustrating. While ostensibly a way to reduce micromanagement, you simply end up constantly redrawing the lines or babysitting units to make sure they do not leave gaps or otherwise behave in ways you do not want. I think that most players of grand strategy games would prefer to simply control their units themselves. While this is an option in-game, by exerting manual control and not using the frontline system, you cannot avail yourself of the important Planning Bonus mechanic that is vital for launching powerful offensives. What makes this even worse is the huge division inflation that takes place towards the middle and late game. Even minor powers will produce massive armies of nearly one hundred divisions, which makes everything a slog and puts a huge drain on older CPUs. The manpower and mobilization systems are incapable of dealing with this, as there are few if any real economic consequences to putting a massive mobilized army in the field once you have the industrial capacity to do so, which is as easy as spamming out enough early-game factories that the game becomes relatively trivial. Economic power and growth is horrendously modeled and entirely fungible.

Overall, the achilles heel of this game is its insistence on making the experience multiplayer-friendly by automatic away much of the intuitive, granular control that is a defining feature of the Grand Strategy genre. The strength of paradox's older, single-player geared titles was the real-time system that allowed the player to vary between speeding through parts of the game while slowing or pausing it to take a more detailed look at events on the ground or plan next moves. "Multiplayer-friendliness" takes away from this experience by orienting the mechanics towards an RTS style, or more accurately a hybrid of Grand Strategy and RTS that can't really decide what it want to do. Unfortunately, I have not bought any of the recent Paradox titles and I do not intend to buy another one unless and until they decide to go back to their Grand Strategy roots.

The Industrial Revolution and its consequences have been a disaster for the human race. They have greatly increased the life-expectancy of those of us who live in ‚Äúadvanced‚Äù countries, but they have destabilized society, have made life unfulfilling, have subjected human beings to indignities, have led to widespread psychological suffering (in the Third World to physical suffering as well) and have inflicted severe damage on the natural world. The continued development of technology will worsen the situation. It will certainly subject human beings to greater indignities and inflict greater damage on the natural world, it will probably lead to greater social disruption and psychological suffering, and it may lead to increased physical suffering even in ‚Äúadvanced‚Äù countries.

The industrial-technological system may survive or it may break down. If it survives, it MAY eventually achieve a low level of physical and psychological suffering, but only after passing through a long and very painful period of adjustment and only at the cost of permanently reducing human beings and many other living organisms to engineered products and mere cogs in the social machine. Furthermore, if the system survives, the consequences will be inevitable: There is no way of reforming or modifying the system so as to prevent it from depriving people of dignity and autonomy.

 If the system breaks down the consequences will still be very painful. But the bigger the system grows the more disastrous the results of its breakdown will be, so if it is to break down it had best break down sooner rather than later.

 We therefore advocate a revolution against the industrial system. This revolution may or may not make use of violence; it may be sudden or it may be a relatively gradual process spanning a few decades. We can‚Äôt predict any of that. But we do outline in a very general way the measures that those who hate the industrial system should take in order to prepare the way for a revolution against that form of society. This is not to be a POLITICAL revolution. Its object will be to overthrow not governments but the economic and technological basis of the present society.

Hearts of Iron IV is a grand strategy game developed by Paradox Development Studio and released on Steam in June 2016. The game takes place during World War II and allows players to lead any nation they choose through the war.

One of the game's strengths is its complexity. The game offers a detailed and intricate set of mechanics, with players managing everything from military strategy and production to diplomacy and politics. The game also offers a wide range of customization options, allowing players to tailor their nation's strategy and ideology to their liking.

The graphics in Hearts of Iron IV are decent, with detailed character models and environments that capture the atmosphere of World War II. The sound design is also well done, with realistic sound effects and music that add to the immersion of the gameplay.

However, the game can be quite overwhelming at first, with a steep learning curve and a lot of information to take in. The game also suffers from some balance issues, with certain nations being more powerful than others.

Overall, Hearts of Iron IV is a highly complex and engaging grand strategy game that offers a unique and immersive experience of World War II. While the game's complexity and learning curve may be a turn-off for some players, those who enjoy in-depth strategy games and the historical setting of World War II will likely find this game to be a rewarding and challenging experience.

Hey there private potato! 

Have you ever wondered what it is like to clap cheeks and ravage the vast marshes of mother Russia? Or play a game that literally no body will complement you on for having thousands of hours in? Well I have just the game for you! Get yourself this game and you will get a taste of how Hitler felt when papa Stalin and Uncle Sam gave him a PP slap in the 1940's. With this fully immersive map game you can not only commit war crimes, but you can get away with it! Hell bring a friend! Geneva? Never heard of that. So come on down and either get your PP slapped or do some PP slapping while frothing at the mouth at 3:27am because Operation Sea Lion is finally happening and the British navy is in Oceania because you have no navy! 

For the low low price of your soul and well over a hundred dollars you can have every DLC known to man AND an addiction not even your wife can give you. This game will give you the new car feeling for your first couple hours as you try to figure out what the fuck you just bought and what battle planning is. 

Want a funny story? No? too bad, I bought this game when i was too young, got addicted, nearly failed a few classes in school because I would play in class. It got to the point that my teacher begun playing it too because he hates communism. 

This game is the most addictive thing ever. You can make a damn bear your president as Poland, or cause Hitler to kill himself in his bunker before the prehistoric war starts. So what are you waiting for private Potato? Get this game today!

Hearts of Iron 4 is one of the best war 2 simulator strategy games that i have been loving now for 8 years. I got the game only a week after release. It's to this day continuing to still get major updates and DLC content added, and the community keeps you engaged with countless amounts of alternative history scenarios like The New Order, or The Kaiserreich. UI wise HOI4 was a massive upgrade over the spreadsheet that was HOI3, making it much more easy and accessible to players to get started. 

You manage everything, from how your country is ran politically, to managing the logistics for your army, and the generals that are in charge to command it. All whitest fighting around the entire world around you. With having the choice of going Democratic, Fascist, or Communist. 

HOI4 is a game that is completely unpredictable, you can have Communist Mexico invading the USA, USSR collapsing in 1940, or even the Ottoman empire being reformed. Every country gets a unique focus tree. 

Legit HOI4 has been one of the best teachers of geography for me, obviously since you are playing on a world map you start to remember where countries, cities. states. where everything is. 

It does have it's faults though. First the AI has been improved since release but sometime's its very janky and unproductive, and half of the time has a mind of it's own on terms of what it want's to do. It would had been a much better idea to have a way for the player to be in control of a lot of how the AI acts, and performs (for example having a more aggressive AI or an less aggressive one) 

The base game itself could use with more playable scenarios would be interesting, such as having a default cold war, or even World War 1 scenario. But it mostly seems paradox are concerned with the current. 

It never seems as well Paradox where concerned for setting up anything that was realistic to how WW2 turned out which isn't a problem, but would be nice if historical focuses actually intended to make it historical.  

Multiplayer doesn't at all feel intuitive to me to play, and always constantly has lagging issues slowing down the game, along with cheaters attempting to ruin it. 

The front line system still feels fairly outdated, and in need of a revamp, along with the retreat line. 
 
Trying to manage your Navy can be a massive hurdle that you hardly half the time spend effort on, since you are primarily  focused on the army and air force. 

The DLC as well is not at any at all reasonable prices, some DLC adds hardly any content into the game (mod's do more then the DLC half the time)

Yeah fuck this game, fun but fuck this game

Edit X2* - 1300 hours
Got 400 more hours out of the base game, and just threw 100 hours into the Old World Blues Mod (Fallout) via Workshop. Tons of fun, and as this game ages the mods and the base game only continue to improve. I shall continue my conquest nerds. 

Edit* - 800 hours
Over 800 hours now, and they finally added something that makes this game so much more realistic I think I'm finally truly happy here. Logistics Management is now a thing. Between Railroads, Supply Hubs, Roads, Trains, and Trucks, the single most difficult thing to effectively manage in wartime is finally here. The ability to have what you need, always, and the ability to take that away from another Country, Sh*t just got real.

I've put in over 500 hours at the time of this review. 
This game has changed a lot, and sees many new improvements, and rebalances as it gets older.
Tons of fun, lots of replayability, and it's a solid challenge. Worth it.

Very well made game, very complicated and i love it.

But they need to fix about Game Features:
- The Hotjoin in multiplayer feature took a long load duration and must wait until the new player joined complete the loading time to resume.
- Can't report toxic players that ruined multiplayer atmosphere.
- Need DLCs to add some Economic and Diplomatic features.
- May add Auto-Join (Host no need approve if someone want to join Multiplayer room) or Need Approval (Host can accept or reject other people to join first) feature to join multiplayer mode if the Hotjoin Loading time already disabled in the future.
- Expanding the timeline from WW2 to Present Day condition would be great for this game.

Overall 8/10

A little hard to understand.

I mostly play on older patches of the game, but its still very fun and has allot of replay value. That said, I wouldn't play without mods as there are several required for quality of life improvements. You'll also find yourself using the diag commands fairly often as there are some ( especially in later versions ) basic functions that are locked needlessly behind other focuses in game. Multiplayer is fun but pretty much requires ALL the dlc to find game and crashes often.

The base game is very fun, complex and difficult. The end game never really felt like it was there and so playing generally gets boring around 1944-45 rather than more exciting. Rather than fixing it or updating the game in any real way, paradox just releases tiny snippets as expensive DLC. Tried their monthly pass to test them and wouldn't pay for any of them. Just sick of the greed and unfinished feel of such an expansive game. Oh, and the online community is somehow the most vile, toxic and intolerable group of people you will ever try to have to suffer through 2 hours of room filling with.

Die Theorie der individuellen Werte unserer St√§mme unterdr√ºckt die Erkenntnis von der Notwendigkeit eines gemeinsamen Willens. Am Ende blieb den deutschen Menschen dann immer nur der Weg nach innen offen. Als Volk der S√§nger, Dichter und Denker tr√§umt es dann von einer Welt, in der die anderen lebten, und erst, wenn die Not und das Elend es unmenschlich schlugen, erwuchs vielleicht aus der Kunst die Sehnsucht nach einer neuen Erhebung, nach einem neuen Reich und damit nach einem neuen Leben.

Als GlossarBismarck dem kulturellen Streben der deutschen Nation die staatspolitische Einigung folgen lie√ü, schien damit f√ºr immer eine lange Zeit des Haderns und des Krieges der deutschen St√§mme untereinander beendet zu sein.

Getreu der Kaiserproklamation nahm unser Volk teil an der Mehrung der G√ºter des Friedens, der Kultur und der menschlichen Gesittung. Es hat das Gef√ºhl seiner Kraft nie gel√∂st von der tief empfundenen Verantwortung f√ºr das Gemeinschaftsleben der europ√§ischen Nationen.

Real review:
This game is a modern history nerd's wet dream. It has extensive modding capabilities. Every game can be wildly different. Most of the countries with playable content are superbly thought out! However, my major complaint with this game is how it is almost required by default to own most of the dlcs. As they give access to almost necessary features. They are almost necessary because it is possible to achieve a fun time without the features. It just makes core aspects of the game harder to achieve. Remember how I said most of the countries with content are good, there are exceptions to this. Over time the idea for content for this game has changed quite a lot. This has negatively affected older dlc. Newer dlc have more complex, fleshed out, and generally more intuitive thought given to each nation. While older ones lack such detail. For example, compare Italy to Japan. Italy has several different paths it can take. And in those paths there are more decisions and choices that one can make. This allows a Italian game to be quite different from one another. Now Japan has a older focus tree. While it is not the worst out of the bunch it still pales in comparison to others. The paths, while unique, lack more of the freedom Italy has with it's choices. This can make a Japanese game feel more repetitive and railroaded. This isn't bad if you want to purely go with historically accurate games, But even then, you can still miss out on greater options and choices that Italy can achieve. 

So in short the game is great you should 100% give it a go if you love history, grand strategy, or heavily modifiable games. There are a few detractors but if you are willing to pay to fix them then I think it's worth it (I mean I gotta justify my 2000+ hours somehow). And you can get this game with it's dlcs on sale for good deals.

I have been playing computer games since I was.....uh, what 12?  I'm now 51, so yes my first gaming was on a 80286.  My point is that I've played a LOT of games over the years.  I have to be careful about when I play Civilization because of how addictive it is.  Yes, I'm one of those people.  

Out of all the computer games I've given large parts of my life to, Hearts of Iron IV is the most addictive by far.  Sit down to play for an hour, look up and four hours have passed.  I suppose for some folks the game won't be appealing, but wow does it have me hooked.  My son (19) is the same way.  Just so much STUFF in it.  You've got to get all the DLC mind you, otherwise you're missing out a LOT.  Some folks gripe about DLC.  If that is a hill you need to die on, play something else.  Me, the money spent on HOI 4 is money extraordinarily well spent.  I'm list right now as playing for 481 hours.  I got the game about 30 days ago, and probably half of those hours is me sitting with the game paused while I'm doing something else.  That stated, that is still 240 hours in 30 days.  There are only 720 hours in 30 days folks!  So yeah, the game is amazing.

Other reviews will go into the details better than I can.  I just wanted to give my endorsement / warning of how engaging this game is.

I love this game if you can't tell by how many hours I have played. I have to be honest unfortunately. This game is like any other paradox game and will kill you with DLC purchases. I believe one they finish this game with full DLC you'll pay roughly $200-$300. Personally I'm fine with it. You the reader are probably less inclined to spend this money. The upside to the DLCs is your paying this money over large periods of time with a few quality of life updates that come at no cost. Paradox isn't doing this to screw you over. They just realize in order to create a great game like this one it costs money and this is the best way to go about it. If you don't enjoy spending money but are still on the fence the modding community is great and you can still have hundreds of hours of game play without the DLC through the mods. I just would not recommend this game to the typical steam players who want a finished game with a one time purchase.

Update: Its now 2024. Returning to my greatest critique, the cost of DLC is roughly $145 and they go on sale pretty frequently. I over estimated by $100ish dollars, but I think this only proves my point as its still a costly game over its life time. That said $60 base + DLC = $205 for a game that's been out for 6 years is only like $30ish a year and thats if you don't do the subscription service or just buy the DLC on sale.

Elysian points out only idiot would buy unit DLC would cause it to rise to possibly $200. There's absolutely 100 ways to skin this cat and figure out how to get the entire game for less... That said, I still standby the idea that the game is great and with mods you can basically just get the game for $60 and enjoy free content without needing to give paradox your money. This game is the ultimate buyer beware as if you don't know about this ahead of time the game can feel pricey and undercooked.

This is my favorite game of all time, as you can probably surmise from my playtime. Played Hearts of Iron III for hundreds of hours, amazed at the uniqueness of being able to play [i] any [/i] country in the world, a concept I had not encountered in any other game. Pre-ordered hoi4, watched the release stream, and started downloading it the second the game was available.

Hearts of Iron 4 is a grand strategy game where you control a nation during World War 2, focused primarily on the military side of things. You are no one in particular - think of yourself as the "spirit" of the nation. But most often you are the government in some form.

You will assume the role of operational command, giving orders to your armies either manually on a division-by-division basis, or by using the battle plan system to give orders to your generals, who will carry them out independently. Often it is a good idea to mix the two. You will also need to command your navies and give your air squadrons their missions.

You will assume the role of a national leader, assigning advisors and generals, dealing with crises, managing diplomatic relations, making executive decisions, and (in the case of the United States) managing your legislature.

You will assume the role of economic and production manager. You will need to plan out your industrial expansion and then assign your military factories to each piece of equipment or category of equipment your army will need. There is one feature here I find particularly interesting. Besides prioritizing specific pieces of equipment depending on what kind of army fits your needs, you will be faced with a decision of efficiency vs capability. Let's say you are producing Panzer IVs. Fantastic. Later with new technology maybe you design something equivalent to a Panther. You cannot simply change from making Panzer IVs to Panthers overnight. Your production efficiency will drop significantly while your factories retool and your workers relearn their jobs. While your newest tank might be much better than the old model, perhaps your Panzer divisions on the gates of Moscow cannot afford the ~6 months to a year drop in production right now. I'm sure your crews would appreciate the additional firepower, but any tank is better than no tank.

There is much I have not covered, such as espionage, managing partisans, changing your government either peacefully or through a civil war, sending "volunteers" to wars while you yourself are at peace, research and design, etc. Suffice to say that if my little aside about production wasn't terribly boring to you, I am either a great writer or (much more likely) this might just be the game for you.

That being said, this is a Paradox Interactive game. This means a steep learning curve, particularly if you are new to this company's games. You will look at the wiki. You will look at YouTube tutorials. You will have 1082 hours in the game and still not fully understand everything in this game (looking at you, naval, air and tank designers). That being said, if you can get past the first 10-20 hours there is a lot of depth here to be found here. You can play as any country in the world. Every playthrough is different. After 1000 hours I still play this and find new things to do and new ways to have fun. If you like strategy or history and have some free time, I highly recommend getting into this game. Think of the learning stage as an investment. You can learn most of what you need to know in a test run of Germany just screwing around, looking at menus, and trying things without worrying about strategy.

Even when you have played every country that interests you using every strategy that interests you accomplishing every goal that interests you, the world of modding beckons. You can visit a hypothetical world where the German Empire won the First World War (Kaiserreich). You can forge a state in the wastelands of the fallout universe (Old World Blues). There are also many mods that simply visit different time periods, such as the modern day and the Cold War (Millennium Dawn and Iron Curtain). Not only do these offer full overhauls of the settings, but will often include vast amounts of entirely new gameplay mechanics and heavily modified existing ones. It's like an entirely new game. There are dozens of mods that have a similar scale and quality to the 4 I just listed.

Of course, If I am to give a genuine review of Hoi4, I need to address Paradox's...[i] unpopular [/i] DLC policies. They tend to release a new DLC anywhere from $10-20 every time they do a significant update which locks some of the update's features behind it. The base game of HOI4 is fun, but not in any way the "full" experience. The DLCs add quite a bit, especially at this point when there are so many. One way to get around this is to play with a friend that owns all the DLC and have them host the game, which gives the content to everyone in the lobby, but this is not a possibility for everyone. I suggest playing the base game and deciding if you like the game enough to fork out the money. Few in the community like this system, but the fact that most people buy them anyways is kind of a testament to the quality of the game, at least compared to others in the genre.

The expansion pass is an option if you want to do a test run of all the DLC or if you think you will only play the game for a month or two, since buying all the DLC, even at like half price on sale, is quite expensive at this point.

But anyways this is getting a bit long. I highly recommend picking this up on a sale if you are willing to put in the time and like this kind of thing.

3,169.5 hours - After 16 attempts at the achievement "Hardly Anything Sevres", and possibly 20-30 hours wasted, I am broken. I did everything right, I followed the guide step by step, but it wasn't enough. After playing Hearts of Iron 4 for almost 132 days, I find my self reflecting. What could I have done or achieved during that time instead of wasting it on countless ruined campaigns, a couple of digital achievement in my steam library? I could've learned a new skill instead, like the guitar. I could've sought new friends and seen new places, but no, instead I played Hearts of Iron 4. I will remember the good campaigns, like defeating the Axis as America, or invading the British Isles as Germany. Even the non-historical games, like reforming the Central Powers and rewriting history. But for now, I say goodbye to you, Hearts of Iron 4.

I give HOI4 a thumbs up, but with reservations.

The core game is alright for a playthrough or two, but it's lacking a certain je ne sais quoi. Here's how I suggest playing the game:

1. Buy the game. Do not buy any DLC; [b]get the monthly subscription for $5 and immediately cancel it[/b]. This will get you a whole month with all the DLC for $5.

2. Try the base game once on historical mode with a country of your choice. A small one is nice to learn the ropes, I think.

3. Once you've done that, go install Kaiserreich and play that instead. It has so much more development effort put into its storytelling and gameplay than the base game that it effectively turns HOI4 into a mere tutorial mode for Kaiserreich.

This game really offers one of the most in-depth combat systems of almost any grand strategy game created by Paradox; there are countless of factors that influence the course of a single engagement between divisions and just as many ways you can manipulate divisions, terrain, generals, and tactics to your advantage. 

The frontline system has only gotten more intuitive as more updates have been released, and the level of organization you can give to operations across a region are very realistic and more refined compared to other Paradox that aren't as warfare focused (EUIV, Vic 2/3). Being able to control a single unit, their entire composition, to running vast armies on a global scale is a feature that almost no other game has replicated. That being said, it is almost solely a game based on warfare. Only the ideology of your country really matters, and you are very limited to what you can do in terms of building up your state in preparation for war. I also found the construction mechanics to be pretty bare-bones and restrictive, almost the entire production/research features are reliant on stacking modifiers (Bigger number = more benefits).

Despite this, the mod community is very active and have created a multitude of mods from alternate history to the modern day, so replay value is almost endless and is enough to recommend the game on its own. I have really only played the base game twice, trying out the major countries and a few minor countries (although they are very grueling/and sometimes impossible to play). Overall, HOI4 is probably the most accessible and detailed game that combines a warfare simulator with the scale of grand strategy, so any fans in that department will feel right at home.

This game (and its devs) definitely both have a somewhat tarnished reputation solely because of how much the dlcs cost for it. Nevertheless, i managed to spend 200 out of my 300 hours in this game without a single one aside from 'historical portraits' and the one for Poland. Overall, the dlcs aren't really a necessity in the end, and even the somewhat bare-bones base game is perfectly fine for an average experience. You don't have to succumb to capitalism to enjoy yourself, no matter what people on Reddit think. I've had tons of fun over the last few months grinding front-lines and killing millions of enemy troops, which was time that I definitely consider to have been worth the money. My suggestion would be to get this game on sale, as it can be like $15 in the right situations, and you will NOT regret it. 
      Also, it might seem a bit difficult at first, but that feeling wears off once you watch some good tutorials and get the hang of things. I still have practically no idea what I'm doing; and that's fine. Also, if one of your friends has the dlcs, you can enjoy them for free in multiplayer; while simultaneously asserting your superiority over them with paratrooper cheese as Italy. 
      TLDR, it's a good game. You should play it.

(Caveman TL;DR at bottom)

2700+ hours. Where did all that time go?

I'd be lying if I said all those hours accumulated solely from the vanilla and DLC that Paradox has to offer. I think Hearts of Iron 4 has a lot to offer, with some of the best combat and most complex systems out there to offer, but without the enormous modding community, I'd probably have dropped this game at 500 hours. Seriously, who wants to play germany for the 40th time in a row on a world conquest save?
This is the one gripe that I have for the game's lack of re-playability. That, and the 70-day focuses. Waiting upwards of 10 real life minutes to finish one is worse than wiping my ass with sawdust and a jar of marmalade. Now, some of the more hardcore fans of the genre might argue that there's plenty to do with all of the nations in the game, but ultimately what separates each country from one another isn't the differing economies, militaries, or tech-trees (all countries share the same re-skinned tech), but the pre-ordained focus trees, which, at best, still only offer you a choice between one of four ideologies: Nazi, dirty commie, "wholesom" democratic, and boring neutral. No joke, but I'm fairly sure a "neutral/authoritarian" run in HOI4 is the cure to all types of insomnia.
This is why I enjoy the mods that this game is compatible with. Mods on the steam workshop alone offer such a variety of different playstyles, scenarios, and revamps, its like a whole bunch of DLC waiting to be picked. With mods, you can break that lack of re-playability with different types of tech-trees, different ways to manage your economy, and even different and alien ways of managing your military, and in the sense of vanilla HOI4, paradox would do themselves good to pay attention to what their community is making. I'd have dropped this game a long while back if it weren't for the few mod-makers who slave away producing quality content.
Oh, by the way: the "my little pony" mod, no matter how "good" it is, can go kill itself for all I care. I don't care about how much effort someone put into it, anyone over the age of 12 who watches this show has some major psychological issues, and needs to check themselves into the nearest ward stat for immediate euthanasia. Without a doubt, one of the standout features of this game is its great historical accuracy. From the military technology to the political landscape, Hearts of Iron IV captures every single detail that leads to and takes place during both WWI and WWII. The level of historical detail in the game is excellent, providing an immersive experience for players navigating through an intricate global conflict.

The game has a large number of countries to choose from that have various national focuses and strategic considerations. Whether you are leading the almighty Soviet Union, the German Reich, or some small nation seeking to alter history‚Äôs path, you will find interesting things with each play through because of the many countries available for play.

Hearts of Iron IV gameplay is intricate yet rewarding. It demands attention to military, economic, and political matters, where players have to manage resources, plan offensives strategically, and engage in diplomatic manoeuvres. Detailed control over military operations comes into play due to the intricate planning system for battles: assigning divisions and coordinating air support.

This aspect has been key in keeping interest in the game high as it continues to be developed further by its modding community. There is a wide range of player-created mods supported by Hearts of Iron IV, including alternative scenarios in history up to total conversions.

If you can get this game on sale, it's really a steal. I've played 280 hours at the time of writing and I haven't played as every country, I haven't tried all strategies. There's like an endless amount of different tactics you can use that keep the game fresh even after having played it for as long as I have. Mods also help a lot with replay-ability. Specifically The Road to 56 is SO good, it basically just takes all of the default things and makes them better and more in depth. Kaiserreich is a close second for me, if you like alternate history. I don't have any of the DLC but I've heard they are good, just expensive. I wouldn't really recommend buying the DLC unless it goes on a pretty good sale.

Edit: over 1000 hours in and a few years later and I am still loving this game, I've barely played any multiplayer and its still so interesting with unique situations happening while playing wacky strategies. Mods still carry this game.

At first I really liked this game. I really thought it was great and the AI was really smart. I spectated the AI and realized they're not smart. The AI doesn't change it's behavior on harder difficulties. You're just given handicaps to limit your abilities. The AI does NOT build new railroads or supply caches, they don't upgrade railroads, they don't increase supply truck usage for an army group. I watched as Germany had -120 steal but refused to upgrade the infrastructure where steal was present or any other resource. I know the AI does build infrastructure sometimes, but Germany was worried about building more military factories, which it didn't need. 

I'm pretty tired of lazy devs making garbage Ai and then just handicapping the player. Maybe get better at your job and make better AI for a more compelling game. ]

Other than this complaint, I think the game is just fine. Just know that once you understand the game, you will always beat the AI with ease, even at the hardest difficulty.

I still like the game and will still play it, but knowing the AI is brain dead makes me not like it as much. It's not a challenge at all.

After installing 2 dozen mods to fix or alter broken or non functional game mechanics, the game is almost playable. Almost.

The key innovations that HOI4 offer in its genre as opposed to its siblings revolve around industrialization of the war machine and the 'frontline' planning system that ostensibly lets you set and forget military frontlines that will then carry out a series of plans that you set for them before hitting execute.

The industrial system is good and I really enjoy the ability to customize units and divisions. This part of the game should be expanded into other paradox titles, and is pretty much the only reason I keep coming back to this game.

The frontline system doesn't work at all and is in all cases worse than simply using the fallback line to specifically say 'stand here, don't move'. Frontlines will split and reassign troops if they encounter impassable terrain or borders of non-hostile nations, resulting in situations where your very simple frontline suddenly has reassigned 2/3 of your troops to a friendly border and the remaining troops are now split between two new frontlines, neither of which inherited the advance orders from the original. 

This is further complicated by the ui for using the frontline system, which took me about 100 hours to get enough of a grasp on that I could make multiple sections of a frontline part of the same offensive. The rest of the UI is just exceptionally bad, even for clausewitz games like this one. 

Diplomacy doesn't exist. It pretends to, but it doesn't. There is no political maneuvering possible like in EU, as the game will bend over backwards to ensure that you are always dragged into amalgamated wars by joining or leaving factions and calling faction members through guarantees. For example, in a recent game I fabricated a claim on afghanistan. China, who was a friendly trade partner of me and hostile to afghanistan, guaranteed them. When I attacked, they joined the war, immediately asked the USA (who they were previously embargoing) to join their faction, were accepted, and then called the USA and the rest of that faction to war against me, which then also called the French faction (with whom I was previously hostile) as my allies against the USA and China and Afghanistan.

Did I mention it crashes to desktop every few hours and hard locks the pc occasionally? Play EUIV instead.

fun game

Pretty nice game overall. Would recommend to everyone. Hoi4 (Hearts Of Iron 4) uses features in war such as supply, logistics, and casualties to a greater extent than most war games. The only item that is crazily misused is the civilian casualties. You could Detonate the entirety of France with nuclear bombs and they would face 0 casualties. However, it is a very unimportant mechanic and most of the time that bug is to your advantage.

Next, DLCS, Hoi4 currently has 9 DLCs. Together for Victory, Death of Dishonor, Waking the Tiger, Man the Guns, La Resistance, Battle for The Bosphorus, No Step Back, By Blood Alone, and Arms Against Tyranny. In the first couple of weeks, you are better off without these DLCs as they are just more stress. The later on you go, the more you find the game boring and unplayable without the 9 DLCs as things varying from Focus trees for minor nations, to Tank, Plane, and Ship Designer, to content online, to just game mechanics in general. I reccomend ALL DLCs to players. 

You are simply missing out without them. But, I think they are only worth their price on sale or discount which Paradox (The developers) tend to discount in major Steam males. (More info can be found about them online.) While all DLCs are a MUST HAVE, I personally don't think they are worth the $20 each. Also Disclaimer: The Ultimate Bundle doesn't include By Blood Alone and Arms Against Tyranny. 

Another option is to get the ultimate bundle subscription which is $4.99 a month which is a GREAT deal considering that the Ultimate Bundle is $170.

Lastly, Hoi4 is a pretty heavy game and it will heat up your laptop without a doubt. As a laptop user, the experience is pretty annoying dealing with the heat and exhaust it gives you but it is not hard to get use to.

All in all, Hoi4 is a great game (And really complicated!) and I highly recommend it to all players.

This game use to be playable, but I am MINDBLOWN at how royally Paradox screwed the pooch on more recent updates...

The game has reached a state of such over-complexity, you have to play for a hundred hours just to understand THE BASICS, at which point, all future learning is about fine-tuning the million-and-one little features that have (overall) have minimal impact on game play.

While Paradox still develops new features and content, the development is extremely questionable, and focuses much more on the "Role play" part of their community... So the newer the content, the more convoluted and overall pointless it is the game play, and health of the game‚Äôs engine. (The supply system overhaul did a hell of a number on that optimization‚Ä¶ now wonder they had to slow the game by 50%... it‚Äôs the only way the AI can keep up anymore.)

And since Paradox, by admission, DOESN'T EVEN PLAY-TEST the game beyond the search for game-breaking bugs, game health and balancing falls entirely on the modders to make it even playable, for the long playtime it was designed for. (At least without being teeth-grindingly annoying and sluggish against horrendously annoying AI.)

They‚Äôve made strides on improving UI, but outside of that, ‚ÄúQuality of Life‚Äù is a term that is apparently lost on the Paradox Developers‚Ä¶ As they‚Äôre more focused on giving do-nothing nations their own content (most of which you will not use) to push for DLC sales, rather than FIXING and improving what they have, in ALL Categories.

Paradox claims to listen to the community feedback, but I don‚Äôt think anyone has actually seen them follow through on those claims (except for a very small number of fanatically obsessed Role Players who do nothing but put this game a on a pedestal in the Paradox Forums‚Ä¶) so what hope I once had about further development for the game has evaporated. Especially when it comes to the growing Multiplayer community of the game‚Ä¶

AND they‚Äôre now pushing a subscription service to sell their failing content‚Ä¶ I think that says all it‚Äôs need to about where this game is heading‚Ä¶ the dumpster‚Ä¶

If you can get it for sale, I wouldn‚Äôt recommend anything less than 50% off. As for the DLC, pirate it. It‚Äôs not worth what Paradox charges anymore. (Hence why they have to sell a subscription to get people to buy it.)

Hearts of Iron 4 is a great game for people who enjoy strategy and are interested in war and history. The game can be a little challenging at first but with a little research and time you can learn the games core mechanics in no problem. Command your armies, naval fleets, and air force on all fronts. organize your logistics, industries, and infrastructure to support your war effort. follow real events as they happen or alter history completely as in hoi4 the player is almost fully involved in the entire world.

Hoi4 offers decent replay value on its own as you can choose any nation you want to play as each with its own differences in ideologies, equipment, geography, and benefits. Some are better off than others as you'll struggle depending on what nation you'll chose. In my opinion most of the replay value comes from the DLC and mods. 
The DLC's are pretty controversial as many of the games mechanics are locked behind them. Many of the DLC mechanics players argue should be included in the base game but you can get by without them.
The games modding community is pretty big so there are plenty of mods that can add hundreds of hours of gameplay to the experience and is the reason I have almost 500 hours of gameplay and no achievements as of writing this. Some mods do more than tweak the just gameplay. There are mods that change the game in unique ways or entirely while keeping the core mechanics. mods include base game overhauls, different time periods, alternate history, or even different franchise such as old world blues which has the game take place in the fallout universe. the possibilities are endless.

Overall I'll break the game down into three scores
Base game is a 6/10
Base game with dlc 8/10
modded 10/10

After almost 500 hours I've grown bored of the game. Its different for everyone as some players have over 1000 hours. At the end of the day I recommend the game especially if you like Strategy games and military history.
