I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Hearts of Iron IV (HOI4) offers a captivating experience with its intricate naval warfare mechanics and a strong focus on historical concepts. The game seamlessly blends strategic depth with historical accuracy, making it a standout in the grand strategy genre.

Naval warfare in HOI4 is a key aspect that adds complexity to the overall gameplay. Players must carefully plan and execute naval invasions, control sea routes, and manage naval fleets to secure dominance over the oceans. The variety of ship types, from battleships to submarines, allows for diverse strategies, catering to different playstyles. The naval aspect adds an extra layer of challenge and depth, making each playthrough unique.

What truly sets HOI4 apart is its commitment to historical concepts. The game meticulously recreates the geopolitical landscape of World War II, from the rise of fascist powers to the alliances and conflicts that shaped the era. The attention to detail in historical events, national focuses, and technological advancements provides an immersive experience for history enthusiasts.

The game's commitment to historical accuracy extends to its realistic portrayal of military doctrines, technologies, and political ideologies. This not only adds authenticity to the gameplay but also educates players about the complexities of the historical period.

While the learning curve may be steep for newcomers, the depth of the naval warfare mechanics and historical concepts rewards players who invest time in mastering the game. The strategic decisions made during gameplay reflect the challenges faced by nations during World War II, making each campaign a dynamic and engaging experience.

In conclusion, Hearts of Iron IV stands out as a grand strategy game that excels in both naval warfare and historical accuracy. It provides a challenging yet rewarding experience for players who appreciate the intricacies of war planning and enjoy exploring the historical nuances of World War II.

Hearts of Iron IV is a captivating and immersive World War II strategy game that offers players an unparalleled experience in global warfare. As player navigating the complexities of historical events, political intrigue, and military strategy, the game provides a thrilling and challenging journey through one of the most tumultuous periods in history.

The attention to detail in Hearts of Iron IV is commendable, with a meticulously crafted map and an extensive array of historical events and decisions that shape the course of the war. The game's focus on authenticity allows players to rewrite history or relive key moments with a level of depth that strategy enthusiasts will appreciate.
The graphics and sound design contribute to the immersive atmosphere, capturing the essence of the era with historical accuracy. The strategic map is visually stunning, and the attention to detail in unit models and animations adds to the overall realism of the game.

I initially brought this since I enjoyed the board game Diplomacy.

At first I did enjoy learning the game but as time went on, it became apparent there was a lot of micromanagement which was not for me. Another major issue is that much of the content also gets samey, although mods helped somewhat.  The fact that a lot of content is behind DLC hampers my perception of this game even more. The base game feels so barebones and after a while, it just stops getting fun. A few mods can somewhat help, but ultimately DLC content seems almost required to enjoy this game more.

If you like micromanagement and WWII era history (which was never that strong for me and continuously waining, another reason why I stopped), I would only recommend this game for its mods and/or if you really want the DLC.

I will be quite honest with you, If the game actually put in an effort of making an actual tutorial, I wouldn't have recommended against this game. However, let's begin. 

[h1] SOUNDTRACK [/h1]

The soundtrack of this game, is not that special, like, at all. It isn't bad to the point you'll mute the game, but it isn't good to the point you'll notice it or listen to the soundtrack outside of the game. However, that's just my personal preference. 


[h1] DIFFICULTY [/h1]
One thing, I like about this game, is that it's only difficult depending on you. Even on the easiest difficulty, and the buffs you can give  to yourself through custom settings, you can still lose, if you make mistakes. That's a good thing, because it means even on easy mode you can't just click on a country for example, invade it, and succeed. You have to put in the effort to coordinate attacks. So if you lose, it never feels like the game was unfair. Rather, it was your own fault. 

[h1] CUSTOMIZATION [/h1]
The game is highly customizable. Even without mods and DLC, you can find yourself playing this games for hours without realizing it. The amount of alternative history routes you could take, is endless. For example in play-through that lasted 10 hours (without me even realizing it), I made an alternative history of causing a Communist revolution in the U.S. converting both Mexico and Canada into Communist states by staging coups, and of course declaring a war on Britain. Further escalating the war even after Hitler and The German Reich collapsed. The play-through was genuinely fun, and I wish to play one where I make the Soviet Union into a democracy, America into a Fascist state, and so many other routes I would like to take. 

[h1]GAMEPLAY [/h1]

The gameplay is fun and enticing. Really, there's everything for everyone, If you wanna run a shadow empire with your own beliefs by staging coops, or look at domestic issues, construct and build a country, invade the country you have a hatred for (I hate Switzerland), simply help out your favorite country in a war because you are too much of a coward to play as them and fend off an invasion, so you just make yourself a re-enforcement (like I did). There is a little bit of something for everyone in this game, you could probably do a play-through without ever directly getting involved in any wars, or be at the prime center of every war and conflict. You could start your own British empire, you could make Communism/Democracy/Fascism spread by staging coops, or you could be a coward and do nothing interesting. 

[h1] TUTORIAL [/h1]

Now, after all these praises, why do I recommend against it? Well, it's because of the tutorial, or lack there of. If you are a complete newbie, and only heard about this game through friends (like I had), and got it. Chances are, you wouldn't know what to do, especially if you are new to this genre of games like I was. If you wanna learn how to play this game; you'll have to either A.) read the wiki, or B.) watch a [b] 6 part [/b] video on YouTube to understand the basics. Now, I was willing to watch the tutorials to give the game a chance, but it doesn't mean everyone will/should. If your game has such an awful tutorial to the point there could be a whole genre of videos of people on YouTube being the tutorial for you; chances are your game isn't worth buying if it isn't friendly to newbies at all. My friend who got me into buying the game had to learn it from a friend. To me, you should be able to pick up a game, play the tutorial, and the rest is up to you to have fun; not for you spend 183 minutes watching a 6 part tutorial, and hope you manage to get the hang of it. People play video games to kill the time, there is a difference between time killing and time wasting. It's tedious that I have to look up a video on YouTube like for example, how to drop a nuke, because the game didn't bother to have a proper tutorial, and only directed me to a wiki. I have never seen a game where there could be an entire genre on YouTube just to teach you how to the bare basics of the game. The basics, the game doesn't even tell you the basics. What do these alerts mean and how do I fix them? Welp, time to Google, or go on YouTube for the 70,000th time. I mean, a game should at least be able to tell you the basics, but it doesn't even do that. 




[h1] CONCLUSION [/h1]]
If you are willing to watch the necessary tutorials on YouTube, or read the Wiki, then this game is fun, and probably one of the best games you could play if you're into this genre of games. However, the fact the tutorial is basically non-existent and you need to rely on the game's community to learn it, just rubs me the wrong way. If you're willing to buy it and again, watch/read external tutorials, I suggest buying it on sale, otherwise you might feel you got ripped off for paying nearly 20 dollars and not even knowing how to play the game properly. Overall; a good game, but the tutorial sucks too much for me to forgive it, and it's a huge issue; it's not new-comer friendly at all. 


[h1] 4.5/10 [/h1]

Players can choose from many different countries, and change the edicts of said nation to fit their own play. Tanks, planes, ships, military divisions, are all customized to make them fit your narrative. In the newer expansions you can upgrade all manner of equipment including Infantry rifles. Combat is complicated at first but the more you understand it the more options you have to conduct your front line warfare. People who love games like Total War would greatly appreciate the details put into this game.

Very immersive and replayable game, but very hard to learn to master. Learn by tutorials and watch lot's of "how to play" videos on YouTube. Works well on multiplay/coop play historical and alternative history. You can play the 'big'/historical countries or dive into any other country on the map.

There are lots of options in the game to work on your Army, Navy and Airforce, but keep your economy at peak level. You can change military designs, divisions, research new equipment and focus yourself on lots of strategical (country) goals. You can micro manage everything up to the battleplans en compositions of your forces. The game is extremely extensive and very daunting for new players when they start to dabble into these types of games. If you are fan of strategic games such as Civilization or Europa Universalis than this game is right for you! For all new players to the genre: keep on trying, make mistakes, learn and you will eventually get the hang of it.

Expansions: Buy only those expansions when you are planning those countries involved into the expansion. Don't buy them full prices as the amount of content is too few to buy them other than on the 50% (or more) off the price.

1. Together for victory       - Canada, Australia, New Zealand, The Raj (India), and South Africa
2. Death or Dishonor        - Hungary,Romania, Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia.
3. Waking the Tiger          - Chinese Republic, Communist China
4. Man the Guns              - The Netherlands, United Kingdom, Mexico and USA
5. La R√©sistance              - France, Vichy France, Republican/Nationalist Spain, Portugal
6. Battle of the Bosporus - Turkey, Greece and Bulgaria
7. No Step Back               - Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and Soviet Union/Russia (Tank designer)
8. By Blood Alone            - Ethiopia, Switserland and (new) Italy (Plane designer)
9 Arms Against Tyranny  - Sweden, Norway and Denmark (Military Industrial Organizations and International Markets)

Overall: 90/100 (good)
-------------------------------------
Learning curve: 3/10 (very steep)
Addicting: 10/10 (extremely good)
Graphics: 7/10 (fair)
Bugs/playability: 9/10 (very good)
Multiplay/Coop: 9/10 (very good)
Price: 8*/10 (good)

*Base game

But... The expansions will add a lot to the game and even when it gets more complex, it is quite fulfilling to do all the micromanaging you want.

[i]In short, HOI4 is a very fun game and possibly the best from Paradox's library, but be prepared to spend.

Mechanics:
The mechanics like stability and war support, and the sheer amount of variables involved, can make the game overwhelming for new players. Once you become more seasoned at the game, it becomes easier to manage and even simple, as with most other games. Be aware if you are thinking of purchasing or have recently purchased the game: it's going to suck learning them. Research is fairly straightforward, but the technologies for designers can be complicated, especially in the late game. Focuses trees are variable, from fun to boring.

DLC:
The thing I tend to despise about this game is the absolute need for DLCs that add little on their own. Each DLC tends to add a new mechanic or two, a handful of focus trees for the region of interest, and some new music. 

AI:
The AI is absolutely braindead, simply put. They do things that make zero sense and only harm themselves. That is all I have to say.

Combat:
This is what distinguishes this game from other WWII strategy games. The combat system is in-depth and a dream for players who want to control every facet of their gameplay experience. You manage your army, navy, and air force in full, including the manufacture of equipment, planes, and ships. You have to ensure that your divisions are supplied, your frontline is stable, your airforce and navy aren't vulnerable, your logistics situation is handled, and more. Few HOI4 players will point to any reason other than the combat system as to the main reason they bought the game. [/i]

I have spent 19 hours playing this game. 
I wanted to get into the Old World Blues mod for it really badly. 
But let me tell you, this game has 100 hour tutorials on the basics for a reason.

I played the tutorial long enough to figure out how to make my troops attack a province because prior to that my troops must have just been sprinting headlong into machinegun fire and at first contact going "Well im not going out there, its dangerous!" Because you have to tell your army that you're at war and where the frontlines are for not just you but the enemy as well. 

I finally got around to going to war in the mod only for my troops to just not care and not listen to my orders even when I hit one of the like 5 different ways to "force" your troops to attack.

There is so much to this game you could have an entire college class on this subject and it wouldnt cover all of it. In fact you should have a second college class going over the philosophy on why anyone would waste their time playing this game for 100+ hours just to learn the basics anyway.

If there was a mod that simplified the gameplay mechanics by making the frontlines for enemy and allied territory just happen instead of me needing to reach out to congess on the matter first or making troop assignments easier or really just cutting out like 70% of the games ridiculously cluttered and out of place UI, anything of the sort that would be amazing. I guess what I'm asking for is a mod that turns this game closer to something resembling Civ 6 which I know I'll catch flak for and people will say "just play Civ 6 then!" but Civ 6 has goofy ass graphics and no Fallout themed mod that I know of so theres that.

Thats enough of my rant.

Played HoI2 back in the days for thousands of hours, so I'm not new to the series, but after only a few campaigns in HoI4 I'm still new to this one.
To sum it all up in general from my point of view: I expected the game to be more polished and functional at this point after so many additions and expansions. The AI is a mess and hopefully HoI5 will implement some sort of totally reworked neural network AI so that the AI can be trained and learn from its mistakes.
As a multiplayer game this might be another beast, if you're into that sort of thing. For me, HoI has never been about multiplayer, but rather an extension of the study of history and making it come alive and all those "what if?"-scenarios and trying them out. Multiplayer is not really suited for that type of play.
To be able to do that you need a competent AI that works in an intelligent manner, but without being predictable. The other big problem is that the AI can easily be "cheesed" and the game soon starts feeling just like a game of Solitaire or Poker, albeit a rather complex one at that.
After having frustrated myself with the idiotic AI in a few campaigns I wanted to see if the AI really is always that bad. So, I let the game run and I just observed what the AI was doing. Every single game runs into the same problems where the AI makes huge amounts of small units and is unable to do anything meaningful for long periods of time. The game starts stalling and units go back and forth without much general coordination and "vision".
I watched Germany stack tens of panzer divisions in Alaska together with Japan trying to go through the Rocky Mountains, where a few Mountaineer units held it without any problems. During Barbarossa Germany starts sending units east through the quite undefended Soviet lands in the south as long spearheads without any backup. I guess they are trying to get to the other front in China. During this the main frontlines practically stood still as units suicided one after another again and again in attacks that never had any chance of success. Generally there seems to be a lack of grand strategy in this game about grand strategy.
These just a couple of general observations from several simulated runs 1936-1950.

For me, personally, I also wish that the developers would add the possibility to streamline the micro management more. Give the option to micro all aspects, but if you're into grand strategy, do you really want to decide exactly what type of radio there is on the tank..? Just give me the grand strategy and the possibility to go and micro manage - if I want.
These two approaches are implemented successfully in many different types of games and applications, so why not here?

The overall presentation is nice, but suffers from the general problem of not being that logical and you just have to learn how stuff works. Intuition isn't really a thing here and I wish Paradox would overhaul some design aspects and bring it to the 21st century. I know, strategy game buffs love to have stuff in a certain way, but it is absolutely not impossible to design better ways of doing old stuff. The National Focus and Research technology trees are two examples where the general idea is good, but the implementation is just horrible. For a HoI4 veteran this is no problem, but why on earth do you design it to be as confusing and overly complicated, when it can be done in a much, much more understandable way..?
I guess the game suffers from the "I love my child even if he's a monster"-syndrome.

This game really scratches that itch for deep strategy and warfare management simulation. Total War games only go so far in challenging that nation builder and conqueror in us. This game doesn't have the visceral and cinematic looking battles but you will swell up with a sense achievement when after many months you finally get your supply lines and infrastructure up to par and you see major progress on one of you front lines as a result.
Have put in over 1200 hours in less than a year and the game makes me want to die. 10/10 would highly recommend.

This game sucks. You play for 200 hours and still can't understand how to actually use your military effectively... the supply system sucks, when I succeed it is always because the AI can't figure out how set up a defensive line and I'm just exploiting it by rushing the victory points, the community is full of borderline n*zis, and I still don't understand why my divisions' organization needs to be above 40 or why I need 10w infantry with anti-air or why the meta changes every DLC. Oh, and as somebody who wanted to play this game watching it on youtube for a while, I was extremely disappointed at the content in the vanilla game, and then learned it would cost me around 80 dollars more to buy the DLC at a discounted price... anyway, this game is extremely complex. If you want to spend 2,000 more hours than I did to feel competent at basic combat, this game is perfect. If you want to have a more strategy based game rather than a math based RTS type game, just play civ6 or one of the various mobile map games out there.

Honestly its one of the games like crack that once you pick it up you can't stop playing it. That being said, that doesn't make this a good game.  There are numerous bugs that just ruin immersion and game play experience. A few of these are front line orders which you need to micro manage to work properly because if you try and use a field marshal to do it it will reshuffle each army every time you take a tile, which leaves you with all of the land that you took open for grabs by the ai because now they're undefended.  If you are losing a tile, you could have 6 divisions on the frontline right next to it watching thinking "damn thats crazy." Not to mention AI being able to bug its way to get advantages that you, the player, are not allowed to do. They can invade your land from neutral countries and push from a tile that you are attacking.  Half the time after naval invading they just get invisible units and you're forced to relaunch the game to be able to see them.  The only real challenge from this game after you play enough is the AI constantly naval invading which you need to keep units ready in your homeland, becoming more annoying than anything. 

TLDR: Its a game you'll play a lot, but hate the entire time. Go play League of Legends for the same experience for free

I have only had this game a week, but have already developed a love/hate relationship with this game. I mean, geez! It's......hard. VERY HARD. This game is complicated to learn, and will kick you to the curb until you either learn it's over demanding mechanics (Imagine Cities Skylines but more micromanaging), or you rage quit. Do not waste time on the tutorial either. It tosses you into the fray as Italy. Tutorial fails to teach you how to effectively do anything. You press buttons and it tells you what it does, but it DOES NOT tell you how to USE the features every menu has. You must manage resources, trade, politics, manage the military of your nation (Which is subdivided by Army, Navy, and Air Force), and also plan how to avoid wars. War is a nightmare for new players because you will not understand how it works. The enemy will either be aggressive (They attack you), or defensive (They wait for you to attack them). This is a complete nightmare if you happen to be fighting an aggressive target such as Germany. Another thing: If you join an alliance, the opposing alliance is going to shaft you unless you are prepared. If you join the Axis planning to just get help conquering a minor nation like Greece, the entire world will turn on you. In my rather pointless tutorial playthrough, I managed to: Lose to Ethiopia, try and failed to be pacifist, caused civil war in Yugoslavia for shits and giggles, join the Axis, fail to protect Albania from Greece, wage war in Greece (Which Germany "Helped" in by attacking a tiny island), and then send an army Bulgaria gave me to take Stalingrad. Time for the pros and cons.

Pros:
There are alternate history paths to look at that will make the game interesting.
Cause civil war in enemy countries by raising party popularity and then starting a coup (Which take time).
You can pick literally ANY country on Earth to play.
Watching the maps change can be fun if you are rooting for the winning side.
In depth tech trees, national focuses, and research trees.
Historical focus that can teach you about WWII if you stay on the historical paths.
Forge alliances or join one.
Active modding community.


Cons:
VERY STEEP learning curve.
Micromanaging gets annoying.
All the resources you need to watch.
Games take a long time (I mean a full day if you are dedicated).
Tutorial completely fails to help new players understand how to play.
DLC is needed for some features.
DLC is overpriced.
Game is WAY overpriced! ($40! I could have gotten a much better game for that price!)

My verdict:
6/10. Miserably challenging game that will drive you mad. You might have fun if you are a grand strategy player, but you will hate life itself if you are hoping for a quick match against the ever more prepared ai. Game has redeeming qualities when you cause the downfall of an enemy through a coup. If you buy this game, don't be a sore loser because this game will win every time if you let it. Go in open minded and fully willing to let the game teach you at it's own mercy (Which can be months, or even years). Stay calm and willing to be defeated, because you will lose a LOT before you win even just one war. Don't waste money getting this thing full price. Wait for a steep sale to pick it up. Finally, consider if you really want this one. Are there games or programs you are more excited for? Consider getting that before this.

Thank you for reading my shockingly long review. Happy Gaming! ~Lard.

Hearts of Iron IV is an amazing WW2 Strategy game. The multiple DLCs for the game expands, or adds, focus trees to the game for countries, that lets you explore historical and alternative paths for countries, while also adding game-play elements which are anywhere from slightly changing the you you play the game, to letting you do things that would be either impossible or very hard to do without the DLCs.
If you get tired of the possibilities of the base game, or the WW2 scenario, then try out the multiple community made mods, that range from exploring the WW2 scenario with more realism, to exploring different parts of human history, to exploring alternative history scenarios, to even venturing into different game/movie/series universes, and more!

TLDR: Hoi4 is a great strategy game that let's you explore lots of different scenarios within the WW2 setting, and even more settings with the use of the game's various DLCs and community made mods.

A Legacy of Strategy

Nestled in the quiet corners of their home, where bookshelves met with memories, Robert often found himself lost in the grand strategies of "Hearts of Iron IV." The intricate dance of nations, the ebb and flow of history, and the pivotal decisions that shaped destinies were elements that enthralled him. But it wasn‚Äôt just the game; it was a connection to a past that he yearned to share with his son, Ethan.

Ethan, a spirited young man with a penchant for contemporary games and technology, often marveled at his father's tales of bygone eras and historical narratives. He listened intently as Robert recounted stories of the World War II era, where alliances were tested, and nations stood on the precipice of change. Yet, amidst those tales, Robert sensed a longing‚Äîa desire to experience those moments together, not just through words but through gameplay.

One evening, with a glimmer of hope in his eyes, Robert approached Ethan. "Son," he began, choosing his words carefully, "Would you like to experience the intricacies of World War II with me? There's a game called 'Hearts of Iron IV' that I think you might enjoy." Ethan, intrigued by the passion in his father's voice, nodded eagerly. "Let's give it a try," he replied with a smile.

As the screen flickered to life, Robert and Ethan embarked on a journey through history, navigating the complexities of diplomacy, warfare, and strategy. Robert guided Ethan through the nuances of the game‚Äîthe delicate balance of power, the importance of alliances, and the consequences of decisions made in the heat of the moment. Together, they orchestrated campaigns, negotiated treaties, and experienced the thrill of victory and the agony of defeat.

With each passing day, Robert and Ethan forged a bond strengthened by shared experiences and mutual respect. Through "Hearts of Iron IV," they explored not just the strategies of war but the intricacies of life itself‚Äîlearning, growing, and connecting on a level that transcended generations.

In the warmth of their home, surrounded by history books and digital landscapes, Robert and Ethan discovered the timeless beauty of shared passions. And as the echoes of World War II resonated through their gameplay, the legacy of a father's wisdom and a son's curiosity intertwined, creating a narrative that would be cherished for generations to come.

Hearts of Iron 4 is a great game. It can keep you going for hours and hours in the base game, especially if you are a history buff or strategy fan. The game provides a recreation of the Second World War, the biggest conflict in history. The game really can make you feel like you a general/leader during the war. 

But that isn't the only thing worth noting, the game has an active modding community brought on by the many tools the game provides. This has spawned countless mods, making it probably one of the most active workshops on steam. When you inevitably get bored of the base game, the modding community provides several new ways to play the game, getting you back for more. 

One of the drawbacks to HOI4 is the amount of money that needs to be spent in order to purchase all the important DLCS. The full experience is rather pricey.

Overall one of my favorite games.

Pork Carnitas 
Ingredients
5lb pork shoulder 
1 chopped onion 
1 Jalapeno no seeds
2 and a half TSP of salt 
1 TSP black pepper 
4 diced garlic cloves 
2 oranges juiced 

Rub ingredients
1 TBSP dried oregano 
2 TSP ground cumin 
1 TBSP olive oil

Instructions 
1. rinse and dry the pork shoulder then rub in salt and pepper
2. combine the ingredients of the rub and then rub onto the pork shoulder  
3. place pork in slow cooker fat side up with the onion jalapeno and the garlic cook on low for 8-10 hours
4. meat should be be tender enough to fall off the bone let cool slightly then shred with two forks 
5. use the juice renaming in the slow cooker and reduce on stove top then use to season the shredded pork

rotting

Hearts of Iron IV is not an accurate WW2 simulator. It is riddled with balances that completely throw off the historical fact that everything was stacked against the Axis, the AI often makes moronic military decisions that even a child would know to avoid and some focus trees for major nations are ancient and in dire need of reworking.

Where this game succeeds however is in its modability. Mods saved this game for me, as the vast number of options and different playthroughs that can be achieved is mindboggling. Despite my initial criticisms, vanilla HOI4 isn't unplayable, there is fun to be had, but it is often frustrating. If you're expecting a realistic WW2 out the box, that isn't to be found here. If you want a sandbox that can be tailored to everything from a ludicrously complicated war simulator to an insane alternate history madhouse, then this is probably the game for you.

In short, HOI4 is a very fun game and possibly the best from Paradox's library, but be prepared to spend.

Mechanics: 
The mechanics like stability and war support, and the sheer amount of variables involved, can make the game overwhelming for new players. Once you become more seasoned at the game, it becomes easier to manage and even simple, as with most other games. Be aware if you are thinking of purchasing or have recently purchased the game: it's going to suck learning them. Research is fairly straightforward, but the technologies for designers can be complicated, especially in the late game. Focuses trees are variable, from fun to boring.

DLC:
The thing I tend to despise about this game is the absolute need for DLCs that add little on their own. Each DLC tends to add a new mechanic or two, a handful of focus trees for the region of interest, and some new music. The game is barebones and almost unplayable without certain ones, and it's extremely discouraging to have to spend a hundred or more dollars until the game is playable.

AI:
The AI is absolutely braindead, simply put. They do things that make zero sense and only harm themselves. That is all I have to say.

Combat:
This is what distinguishes this game from other WWII strategy games. The combat system is in-depth and a dream for players who want to control every facet of their gameplay experience. You manage your army, navy, and air force in full, including the manufacture of equipment, planes, and ships. You have to ensure that your divisions are supplied, your frontline is stable, your airforce and navy aren't vulnerable, your logistics situation is handled, and more. Few HOI4 players will point to any reason other than the combat system as to the main reason they bought the game.

400 hours worth of two player co-op against AI ideas, and I loved every minute of it:
Disclaimer: this is my only experience with Hoi4, do not use any advice given for PvP. 

As a general theme in two player co-op: since, without your interference, the axis usually wins already, I recommend only aiding them if you plan to fight them later on. 

USA + Britain aka "decadence": Start in 1939 and join the Allies. Special rules: only the most expensive and decadent things are allowed (tanks including AA/spg variants, mechanized infantry, strat/tac bombers, battlecruisers, battleships, nukes and rocket silos). Only exception is infantry equipment for your mechanized units and trucks for supplies (since your decadent ass has motorized supply on max by default obviously).  Disband/destroy what does not fit the category above. We ended up losing Britain against the axis fleet, so we kept our starting cruisers as a comprimise. Especially the beginning will be tough, since mechanized infantry has to be researched first. Pulling off naval invasions without infantry is also challenging. Also finding a place to nuke without having fighters for air superiority is a fun little challenge.

Sweden + Finland aka "Schneegammler (Snow Loafers)": Finland¬¥s new focus tree makes this especially fun. Remenber Finland cannot change ideology (as far as I know of). Either form a large scandinavian alliance or Sweden goes for the Kalmar Union. After fighting the winter war for some time, take on the axis in mid to late game. Either share the soviet territory with the axis first or fight them alongside with the Soviets. Making the Soviets ironically somewhat of an ally to you, since you already weakend them in the winter war and you will likely feel sorry for them. 

Soviet Union + communist India: fight both the axis and allies. Lots of options to occupy minor nations along the way.

facist Iran + fascist Turkey: tried an early war against the soviets but did not get very far until the axis arrived. No hope fighting them after the peace, but maybe you will fare better! An alternative would be to fight the allies and form the Ottoman Emire. 

France + Czechoslovakia (small entente): defence focused game. Czechoslovakia can core much of eastern Europe later on. Fight the soviets later on if you want to stick around until the late game.

fascist Britain + Japan: mostly did that one to challenge the US navy early on. Japan had an easy time invading since most of the US fleet focused on the Atlantic. 

Poland + neutral Japan: Fun option for an early war against the Soviets. Give up Danzig to buy time and prepare for a tough fight against mid/late-game axis. 

Manchukuo + Communist China: really love the Manchukuo independence focus tree. Enjoy gobbling up nationalist China and the remaining warlords while everyone is fighting Japan at the same time. 

Fascist Peru + fascist Brasil aka "South American Union/SAU": unify central and south America. Peru is one of the nations that can form Gran Colombia. The allies were surprisingly passive during our conquests. Both Mexico and the US posed a fun challenge. 

Germany + fascist France aka "Kohle und Stahl": Easy combo for a world-domination run. Well suited for inexperienced players.

Jugoslavia + Czechoslovakia aka "no one saved us, no one saved us. No one saved us, no one's gonna save us now". One of our all time favourites. Taking Austria early on is an option to shorten the frontline with Germany somewhat. Good luck!

Italy + Romania aka "Two wings, one eagle": rush into France and Britain if you can. Use the new focus tree and the industry you¬¥ve conquered to show Germany who is the hegemon of Europe. Dont forget to sponsor your buddy Romania. 

Poland + Austria-Hungary aka "The Neutrals": Try to survive an early war against Germany. 

Communist South Africa + minor nation: we went with releasing and playing Egypt, but middle eastern minors work too and are generally stronger. Focus is on Anti-Colonialist crusade and creating lots of new nations. Take on axis once the allied territories in Africa are taken. Expand into Asia and Australia if you are bored since expanding into Europe will be tough.

Hearts of Iron IV is one of the best, if not the best, strategy war games I have played. There are multiple countries to play as, numerous scenarios to scope out, and hundreds of amazing mods that help make the game feel more updated and entertaining. It seems to me that even though I may play the same eras over and over again, it still never truly feels boring, as every time there is something new I want to do. You can even annex Germany as New Zealand if you want too! Beginners to the game may feel a bit swamped with learning how to play the game at first, but once you get going and work out the controls and mechanics, it feels more rewarding. Usually, depending on what mods you install, your computer shouldn't have a hard time running the game, and bugs tend to be more on the less frequent side. The music within HOI4 is also exemplary. As mentioned before, there are many mods out there for HOI4, and some I'd recommend are: Kaiserredux, Pax Britannica, The New Order, and Millennium Dawn.

[h3]üèÜ FINAL RULING üèÜ[/h3]

After playing maybe 100 hours of the base game and 700 hours of mods, I can now say that the WW2 aspect of this game is complete bullshit.  Don't buy this for their take on the game, it's over inflated with stuff that doesn't matter and it's general isn't an enjoyable experience when you spend 5-6 hours just getting to the beginning of the war and realizing if your not playing one of the main factions your time was worth nothing.

Now the mods are amazing.  If they were to team up with the makers of the Old World Blues mod and make that the MAIN game they would be hitting it out of the park.  You can play almost any faction in that and have an enjoyable time from start to finish.   If you get this game, download that mod first and ignore the base game.  Also the Pony mod... But Reddit gets angry if you like the Pony mod.

I am only recommending this game for the mods, or maybe if you play multiplayer and remove all the AI with people.

Hearts of Iron IV is a management sim where you oversee the European real estate ambitions of an unsuccessful Austrian Painter and avid Opera Fan.

It took me a very long time to organize my thoughts on HOI4 and whether or not it's something I recommend playing but ultimately I believe that it's flaws already outweigh it's virtues and that it's moving continuously in a poor direction albeit at a glacial developmental pace. I think the biggest problem with it is that HOI4's greatest potential is as an alternate history roleplaying game and story generator but that it generally forgoes achieving that in favor of pleasing an obsessed cadre of sweatlords who endlessly cry out for increased difficulty and granularity so as to increase the need to metagame and to grant more tools to metagame with. Worse yet they do so primarily to serve a multiplayer mode for a game which frankly isn't really built to be a good PVP game and where the AI certainly isn't prepared to survive a coordinated co-op assault made upon it by multiple competent players let alone expert ones.

There are quality alternate history and total conversion mods for the game that are ultimately closer experiences to what HOI4 would be in a more optimal state of pursuing the real strengths of the concept and the core mechanics but I'm reluctant to recommend a game based purely on it's mods. The reason for that is that Paradox could just up and decide any day to cut mod support or shut down the workshop page, likewise any given mod dev team could just socially implode over discord drama or casually lose interest at any time and stop making updates to keep their mod functioning as Paradox continues to perpetually monkey with the base game.

The most fun way to play HOI4 is to run just enough mostly historical games to get a good grip on the systems and then try your luck at new playthroughs as any of the given major powers with all of the rest of the nations in the world set to random focuses so that you actually have to truly play the game intelligently instead of exploiting your prescient real world knowledge of history. Oh and you're also going to want to nearly always play as Fascist or Communist regimes because by mechanical necessity democratic gubberments are entirely reactive and usually don't get to have any fun until the early 1940s in a game that starts in 1936.

Do I regret buying HOI4? No, but I would regret it if I hadn't scooped in and most of the DLC up during massive sales, something that will probably be less of an option for new players going forward given Paradox's movement toward a subscription model. I also have to wonder how many tiresome mechanical sandbaggings like the current abysmal supply system will continue to be implemented going forward in yet more attempts at wrangling the ever meta optimized and explosive aggression of the sweatlord population who continue to unfailingly purchase low-content twenty dollar DLCs day one year in and year out even after having dumped tens of thousands of hours into the game each.

Take this review as a minority report from a guy who is autistic enough to have enjoyed learning to play HOI4 but who isn't enough of a turbo-autist to turn it into the kind of anal retentive lifestyle it's target audience and biggest fans make it into.

If HOI4 does still interest you though I would suggest doing what's always the wisest with every paradox game, wait until that day in the future when they finally abandon the thing and put together a complete edition of it sold at a single semi-reasonable price.

I have only played this for a handful of hours compared to most other players. But I will have to say that the detail and strategy is exceptional. You can literally command individual Infantry Divisions, Air Wings, Naval Fleets, Armor Divisions, Mechanized Divisions, ect. You can plan Naval Invasions, Air Invasions, Draw Front lines, and a whole lot of stuff in the Economy and Production departments. The game is broad and complex at first but you get use to it after awhile. The combat is entertaining and it has a feeling of accomplishment. For those strategist and WWII fans out there, I highly recommend this!

I would recommend the game, but also warn people that it still needs ALOT of AI fixes. 
Infact you're almost certainly better off not having AI allies in their current state, as they will actively seek to expand wars they're winning, before you can win the first war.

Given also the serious issues with front line mechanics as you advance/retreat where some army groups will exspand over entire frontlines randomly covering the area's also covered by other armies, spreading themselves far too thing and leaving your entire front open to encirclements, breakthroughs and capitulations. It needs ALOT of work. To the point that you are often better off micromanaging your battles, and are often forced to do so.

Lovecraftian creature of a game that will not compromise with you - you will either get turned off by it within the first hour or it will end up as one of your most played games. It is an incredibly versatile strategic/political simulator with a questionable quality of "vanilla" gameplay but practically endless potential to create, tell and experience new deep stories and gameplay experiences via free modifications, towards which HOI4 is practically oriented. For the latter part, I can definitely recommend it - you wouldn't really need DLCs to enjoy most mods, either.

[h1]Hearts of Iron IV: A Deep and Complex Strategy Experience! ‚öîÔ∏èüåç[/h1]

Hearts of Iron IV is a war strategy game developed by Paradox Interactive. This game provides a deep strategy experience by presenting players with historical events and decisions during World War II.

üëç [b]Pros:[/b]

[b]Historical Depth and Detail:[/b] The game stays true to the details of the World War II era, while offering players many different countries and strategy options.
[b]Comprehensive Gameplay:[/b] Combining various elements such as diplomacy, military strategy, economics and politics, it offers a comprehensive strategy experience.
[b]Mod Support and Community Content:[/b] The game offers players an expandable platform with mods and rich content created by the community.

üëé [b]Cons:[/b]

[b]High Learning Curve:[/b] Since the game has deep strategic elements, the learning curve for new players may be high.
[b]Optimisation Issues:[/b] The game may experience performance issues when running on a large scale.

    [tr]
        [th]Features[/th]

Hearts of Iron IV offers a highly satisfying experience for fans of strategy games with its historical detail, deep strategy and expansive gameplay. The high learning curve and performance issues may affect some players, but overall it offers rich content and strategic depth. Its fidelity to historical detail and the freedom to move between different countries draws me into the game. However, the steep learning curve at the beginning and some technical issues can hinder the fluency of the game a bit. Still, I think it's a must-try for anyone who loves war strategy and historical scenarios!

Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ (5/5)

Overview:
Hearts of Iron IV (HOI4) redefines the grand strategy genre, providing an unparalleled experience in the intricacies of global warfare, politics, and diplomacy.

Highlights:

Gameplay (5/5): Unmatched strategic depth, military planning, and historical accuracy make HOI4 a captivating experience for seasoned war strategists.

Graphics and Sound (4.5/5): Immersive visuals and authentic sound design bring the battles of World War II to life, enhancing the overall historical atmosphere.

Diplomacy and Espionage (4.8/5): The game intricately weaves diplomatic intricacies and espionage into the narrative, allowing players to shape the course of history through alliances and covert operations.

Multiplayer Experience (5/5): Multiplayer mode shines with intense, player-driven conflicts, offering an unpredictable and dynamic global stage for strategic showdowns.

Replayability (5/5): The extensive modding community, diverse national focuses, and historical paths ensure each playthrough feels unique, promoting endless replayability.

Conclusion:
Hearts of Iron IV is a triumph in the grand strategy genre, providing an immersive and challenging experience for history enthusiasts and military tacticians alike. Whether rewriting history or forging a new path, HOI4 stands as a definitive title in global warfare simulation.

I wanted to make this review short and sweet, but it's hard to stop writing, even when excluding facts that could potentially contaminate an exceptionally well thought-out gaming experience. There's just so much to say. Half-Life 2 is, simply put, the best single-player shooter ever released for the PC. It does so many things right in so many ways that it might be possible to write a thesis on the topic of Half-Life 2 compared to other single player shooters. What Valve has created is simply a masterpiece -- a work of art in the genre. Not only does it engage the mind with mysterious happenings, vagaries, and mostly intelligent dialogue, but also captures the senses with a superb visual style made possible by brilliant technology. And once the initial shock of it all wears off and it becomes possible to peel back the polished layers of sight and sound, there is an excellent shooter here. Half-Life 2 doesn't do anything particularly new; it doesn't really innovate in many ways. But what it does is set a new height for all other designers of first-person shooters to reach. It still isn't exactly perfect, but it's about as close as I've seen in my tenure here.
Before I really get into the review, you should know the background of how this game was reviewed. Valve did not want to send out copies of their game (for fairly obvious reasons) before it was released to the public. In order to play the game, I, and several of my colleagues throughout the industry, took a trip up to Seattle to visit Valve in order to have some private time with the title. I was given a little room to myself where I could close the door, turn off the lights, click my little red slippers, and pretend that I was sitting at home. It worked for the most part, largely because I was so engrossed with the game that when I came out of my trance I often had to take a moment to get my bearings. Obviously, Valve was happy to bring me into a controlled environment for ideal playing conditions.

The system that I played the game on had these specs:
ASUS P4C800-E dlx motherboard
Intel P4 3.2GHz CPU
2.0GB DDR400 dual-channel RAM
Radeon 9800PRO 128MB video
Creative Audigy 2 ZS sound
Western Digital 160GB SATA HD
Obviously, since we were only allowed to play the game at Valve, this is the only system that we've had the chance to play with. That said, at 1280 resolution, the game ran flawlessly, even in the most extreme environments with tons of geometry and lots of objects moving around, both with and without AI. The Source engine is an impressive piece of software from the outside looking in. There's a large chance my brain would melt like Velveeta in a microwave should someone try to explain its inner workings.

What's particularly impressive about the game running so well is that it does so without compromising any part of gameplay or design. Environments are complex, colorful, and highly detailed; AI is certainly impressive in that NPCs work as teams, flank, react to sound and movement, and then engage with lifelike aggression. But like I said, we're going to have to wait and see what the game runs like on a more standard system after it's released. Therefore, you can look for an additional supplement to this review about how the game runs on lower-end systems after we've had the chance to check.

The other problem with reviewing the game up at Valve is the simple fact that we couldn't test out Steam and how well the product registration system necessary to playing Half-Life 2works. I'm not exceedingly happy about the forced registration even if it is understandable in today's climate of highly pirated games, though I can't say I believe this will stop ultra-determined hackers from cracking the game regardless.

Still, no matter what you think of Valve's business policies, Half-Life 2 is a "must buy" game. If you're a fan of the series, that was already obvious. Heck, if you're a PC gamer chances are you're going to get it at some point anyway. But if you're new or skeptical of the genre and want to see a prime example of the power and excitement of a first-person shooter, this is it. And it begins with the continuation of a story.

Wake Up and Smell the Ashes...

Last time we left Gordon Freeman, the unlikely scientist-hero from the first Half-Life, he was traveling. Yes, just traveling. The mystery was where he was traveling to and why all of the incidents at Black Mesa had happened (not to mention why the game was rife with so many horrific jumping puzzles towards the end). Half-Life 2 begins with Gordon arriving via train with the G-Man teasing his mind with sickly whispers of warning. The last stop of the arriving train is City 17, a bastion of the alien Combine forces, yet another mystery themselves.

For the rest of the story, you'll have to play the game yourself. I'm absolutely dedicated to getting through this review with your chance at an untarnished gaming experience intact. That means no spoilers. Suffice to say, there are lots of twists to curl your brain along the way, some a bit more predictable than others, but all welcome and interesting.

While the writing and plot points will act as fly paper to your attention, the real winner here is the way the story is presented. Through the eyes of Gordon Freeman, you'll experience roughly 17-20 hours of consciousness which tests your senses and captures your mind. The simplicity and style with which this story is presented are perhaps the most graceful maneuvers of the many that Valve has carried out. From the moment you take your first steps off of that train and into the station at City 17, you'll begin to be tutored in the ways of this bizarre eastern European city. Public service announcements, private conversations, and the actions of characters around you, whether part of the Combine or simply waylaid citizens, create a stifling and threatening feeling that City 17 has become some sort of elaborate prison preaching the chance for freedom and opportunity without choice or desire.

While I was ultimately left a little bit frustrated by the open-endedness, the journey to get to the end of the story was assuredly interesting and opened up the doors to many more possibilities. It's easy to start speculating about this or that, just don't let it drive you nuts. The deeper you get, the darker and more intriguing it becomes until you get to the end... which you'll have to see for yourself.

Where to begin? If you‚Äôve never played a paradox game, you are walking into an investment. Paradox games are insanely expensive over time. Just look at the current DLC price total, $204. This is par for the course with paradox. Now for that you get a living, breathing game. This game is pushing ten years old and consistently remains on the daily top 100 played games. The DLC‚Äôs for the most part are well put together (after a few weeks of bug fixes) and not required. Many of the complaints about HOI4 are due to the DLC practice, if that bothers you stay away. For me it‚Äôs the price to pay for a game to receive this type of long-term love. Price per an hour of play time is the metric I use and HOI4 is a solid game for me.

Now for game play. The vanilla game is very good but where the game truly shines is with the workshop. I haven‚Äôt played a pure vanilla game in years. There are far too many outstanding mods out there. Because this is an investment, take some time to look through the workshop. To say this game has replay value doesn‚Äôt quite do it justice. After monkey stomping German/Russia and restoring PAX Britannia for a few days, I moved over to stopping Mordor from invading middle earth. Again, an insane amount of replay ability beyond just WWII. For WWII it is unmatched, as should be expected. You can read anyone of a hundred reviews to get your head around that. On a final note, almost anything you don‚Äôt like has been or can be removed or modified with either console command or mods.

This game takes a stupid amount of time to learn, so prepared for dozens if not hundreds of hours to feel satisfied on that front. However, that doesn't mean I didn't have fun early on, even if I was totally lost. I'd recommend watching youtube videos on hoi4, whether its informational or just entertaining, it'll end up making your experience more fun. If you don't have DLC (buy the subscription!!!), just play mods it'll still be fun, I recommend kaisereich and kaiseredux greatly (it's how I got into the game). It definitely helps to have historical knowledge/generally be interested in history to play this game, its a ww2 simulator afterall. Reddit is by far the best resource I have found for any questions you have. Overall this game is very fun, but be prepared to but a lot of hours into it.

TLDR; Unless you want to cheat or put in thousands of hours into this game, don't buy it.

Bought this game soon after it was released and initially had a good time. Was thinking of getting back into it when I saw some DLCs on sale. However, the game is incredibly time-consuming. Every new DLC feels like starting over in terms of learning. There are lots of guides, but it's hard to tell if they're current or relevant to the DLCs you have.

The biggest issue is the long-term impact of early decisions. Make a mistake in research or your tank template early on, and it can ruin your entire game. 

If you're not willing to invest a huge amount of time or resort to cheating, this game might not be worth it

When I tried to get a refund, I found out I had already spent too many hours just trying to learn from guides and YouTube videos, which, as it turns out, were outdated.

From Convictions to Conquests: My Journey Back to the Frontlines in Hearts of Iron IV

Hearts of Iron IV, the game that became my unexpected salvation after a tumultuous hiatus from gaming. Two years ago, I was in a dark place, serving time for a series of regrettable decisions that involved catalytic converters and a battle with addiction. Fast forward to the present, and here I am, back in the gaming world, specifically with Hearts of Iron IV, marking a significant chapter in my life's turnaround.

This World War II grand strategy game has been more than just a source of entertainment; it's been a catalyst for personal redemption. The intricate details of war planning, diplomatic maneuvering, and the sheer complexity of global conflict in Hearts of Iron IV served as a mental escape and a welcomed challenge that demanded my focus and strategic thinking.

As I navigated the intricate political landscapes, engaged in intense battles, and reshaped the course of history within the game, I found a renewed sense of purpose and accomplishment. Hearts of Iron IV became a symbol of my commitment to a better path, replacing destructive habits with a constructive and intellectually stimulating pursuit.

The game's ability to immerse players in the intricacies of wartime decision-making provided a therapeutic outlet, allowing me to channel my energies into a world where consequences were virtual and choices were strategic rather than destructive. It's not just a game for me; it's a personal testament to the power of turning one's life around.

So, here's to Hearts of Iron IV for being more than just a game ‚Äì it's been a companion on my journey to redemption, reminding me that even after a tumultuous past, there's always a chance to rewrite the future. Onward to victory, both in-game and in life!

[h1] The 1000 Hour Review [/h1]

[b] Personal opinion and introduction [/b]

As a history and military enthusiast, as well as a gamer, this game is in my eyes a masterpiece.
The amount of detail when it comes to a country's history, politics, culture, etc., is astonishing. The game gives you control over a nation's politics, economy, industry, foreign relations, navy, air force, army, intelligence agency, and more. -Which introduces a major point in this review; it's complexity.

[b] Complexity [/b]

The game is super complex compared to many other games. This is something I personally like, as I can learn something new even after a thousand hours of play time. The fact that you don't know every aspect of the game, doesn't make the game unplayable. Though, I acknowledge that many players don't like the game because of the massive learning curve. I do believe it all comes down to your mind set, and that you shouldn't expect to be great in the beginning. This is not like an fps where you know the controls from before starting the game.

Despite the game obviously focusing on the major nations of the early to mid 20th century, even small nations get something unique. As a soldier myself, at the time of writing this review, with my immense patriotism for my country, I enjoy the small details in my homeland, even though it's a minor country.

[b] Community and Modding [/b]

The HOI4 community is a large community mixed with a lot of different people. Despite some people claiming the HOI4 community is toxic, I know this isn't the case for most of it. I myself, don't really take part in many discussions on for example the hoi4 subreddit, but I do enjoy the memes and posts that are posted there. It's worth mentioning that the game features a multiplayer mode, which is fun if you have friends.
[url=reddit.com/r/hoi4] HOI4 subreddit [/url]

The countless mods people create for this game, makes it so much better. You never run out of content. If you are looking to become a modder yourself, this game is perfect. I have modded a little bit for it myself, and I can tell you it's actually quite simple.

[b] Performance [/b]

This game is poorly optimized, and CPU heavy. You basically don't need a grapichs card, as it's mainly your CPU that does the work. You see, the game doesn't really have advanced reflections or realistic graphics. (Duh, it looks like a board game.) Though, the CPU has a lot more work to do, as every nations units, stats, planes, battles, and more needs to be calculated accurately. This game is not for "weak" computers, unless you plan on not playing through the late game, or installing a performance boosting mod.

[b] Conclusion [/b]

This is one of my favourite games, and I can't recommend it more.
If you enjoy grand scale strategy games, are interested in history, and like games that are not fast paced, this is the game for you.

I love this game so goddamn much. Hearts of Iron IV, affectionately known as HOI4, stands as a testament to Paradox's mastery in grand strategy gaming. This World War II simulation is a brilliant blend of historical accuracy and strategic depth that captivates from the first click. What sets HOI4 apart is not just its robust gameplay mechanics and meticulous attention to historical detail, but the vibrant modding community that breathes new life into the experience.
The modding scene for HOI4 is nothing short of extraordinary. From total conversion mods that transport players to alternative historical scenarios to intricately detailed overhauls, the creativity of the modders knows no bounds. This community-driven content ensures that every playthrough can be a unique and fresh experience, extending the game's longevity far beyond its initial release.
Yet, the true brilliance of HOI4 shines when you gather friends for a multiplayer session. The collaborative aspect of planning and executing military strategies adds a layer of excitement that single-player experiences often lack. Whether coordinating intricate battle plans or facing off against each other in epic clashes, the multiplayer dynamics elevate HOI4 to a whole new level of enjoyment. Nothing better than kicking the homies asses!
The game's interface is user-friendly, making it accessible for both seasoned strategy veterans and newcomers alike (despite the claims of some of my friends. It‚Äôs really easy to learn compared to other strategy games). The attention to detail in historical events, coupled with the strategic decision-making required, creates an immersive experience that feels both challenging and rewarding but sometimes frustrating considering that bots suck.
In summary, HOI4 is a strategic masterpiece that not only captures the essence of World War II but also provides a dynamic platform for player creativity through its robust modding community. The multiplayer experience adds a social dimension that makes every session great for hanging out with friends, shooting shit, and watching your empire fall apart due to nukes. Paradox has not only delivered a stellar historical strategy game but also fostered a community-driven environment that ensures HOI4 remains a staple in the genre for years to come and I am very grateful for that. Buy the game please, it‚Äôs great!

Oh, let me tell you about the absolute travesty that is Hearts of Iron IV. This so-called "game" has single-handedly ruined my life, turned me into a shell of my former self, and obliterated any semblance of productivity that I once had.

It all started innocently enough. A friend recommended Hearts of Iron IV, promising an immersive World War II strategy experience. Little did I know that this game would become a vortex, sucking away every ounce of free time I ever had. Forget about socializing, forget about responsibilities ‚Äì Hearts of Iron IV demands your undivided attention.

At first, it seemed harmless. I'd sit down to play for just an hour or so, thinking I could conquer a few countries and call it a day. Oh, how naive I was! Hours turned into days, days turned into weeks, and before I knew it, I was knee-deep in a virtual war, completely detached from reality.

The graphics are so captivating, the sound effects so realistic that you find yourself lost in the chaos of battle. I can't tell you how many times I've screamed at my computer screen, blaming the AI for my failures. It's not me, it's them! But deep down, I know the truth ‚Äì Hearts of Iron IV has turned me into a warmonger, a dictator with a god complex, manipulating the fate of nations from the comfort of my gaming chair.

And don't even get me started on the steep learning curve. I thought I was a strategic genius, but Hearts of Iron IV humbled me faster than you can say "D-Day." The intricacies of production lines, resource management, and battle plans are enough to make your head spin. I've spent more time watching tutorial videos than I have on any other form of education in my life.

But the worst part? The community. I've fallen into the dark abyss of forums and Reddit, discussing optimal division templates and arguing about historical accuracy. It's a black hole of opinions, and I can't escape. My real-life friends have become mere shadows, replaced by online comrades who understand the importance of encirclement and the terror of the dreaded supply lines.

So here I am, a mere husk of the person I used to be, haunted by the echoes of air raid sirens and the incessant clicking of division placement. If you value your sanity, stay away from Hearts of Iron IV. It's not a game; it's a life-consuming vortex that will drag you into the depths of historical warfare, never to return. Save yourself while you still can!

Hearts of Iron 4 √© um dos melhores jogos de Grand Strategy j√° desenvolvidos na hist√≥ria. Absurdamente viciante, divertido e uma verdadeira aula de hist√≥ria para os amantes da Segunda Guerra Mundial. Quem procura uma experi√™ncia na qual pode mergulhar em aspectos detalhados da estrat√©gia de guerra certamente se divertir√° muito com HOI4. O jogador toma grandes decis√µes para o pa√≠s, pesquisa cada componente tecnol√≥gico para suas for√ßas armadas, lida com a produ√ß√£o de todos os aspectos b√©licos da na√ß√£o, constru√ß√£o de infraestrutura, log√≠stica e, claro, a estrat√©gia de campo, onde comanda ex√©rcitos e divis√µes para garantir a sobreviv√™ncia do pa√≠s na guerra mais destrutiva da hist√≥ria.

Al√©m de sua estrutura complexa e da quantidade absurda de conte√∫do, HOI4 oferece uma "replayabilidade" imensa, j√° que √© poss√≠vel escolher qualquer pa√≠s e explorar diversas estrat√©gias durante o conflito, cerca de 3 a 4 caminhos distintos, dependendo da na√ß√£o.

S√£o in√∫meros status, modificadores, detalhes e outros aspectos da forma de jogar com cada pa√≠s que exigem alguma leitura, √†s vezes at√© alguns tutoriais online para se aprofundar. No entanto, isso n√£o impede que os amantes de estrat√©gia e da Segunda Guerra Mundial se divirtam muito, mesmo que a estrat√©gia n√£o funcione completamente.

Uma breve an√°lise das expans√µes tamb√©m √© relevante para os jogadores que desejam entender o que elas representam antes de considerar a compra. Caso esteja buscando come√ßar com um bom jogo, sugiro:

Vers√£o Base

Opcionais:

If you are looking for a game to start your adventure with grand strategy games by Paradox, it's the best game you can start with. It does not mean it is gonna be easy. The Game has in-game tutorial, which is pretty good. However, it's definitely not enough to explain all mechanics. But the great thing is - you do not need to know about all things. The tutorial gives you basics of each gameplay aspects, then you can focus on a single mechanic, master it, and repeat. And after some time you feel pretty comfortable with the game. Also, I think HOI has the biggest community, so it's easy to share experience and learn from others.

Was a huge fan of Hearts of Iron 3 back when I was younger so when I saw HOI4 I knew I had to get it. While I miss the more in depth army organization with corps, armies and army groups of HOI3, the ability to really design divisions, and the sheer modability more than makes up for it. Par for the course as a Paradox Game with DLCs but by far one of my favorite games. It's a lot of fun for casual and competitive play. Repainting the maps or exploring the worlds of Kaiserreich, Old World Blues or the many other fantastic overhaul mods. Getting to rewrite history can be incredibly satisfying or sometimes a complete struggle. Definitely worth it.

Too micro-intensive to be enjoyable. When I bought HOI 4, I assumed the battle planner would be a revolutionary feature, allowing the player to elaborate intricate strategies on the campaign map and letting the AI do their thing.

There are too many pop ups, you have to constantly micro your supply, air, navy, industry and production, then watch out for fuel and resources, and since the game gives so many bonuses to the defending side, you have to micro your divisions constantly if you want to acheive a breakthrough.

You will find yourself piinning enemy divisions, assigning hotkeys to tank divisions, clicking for encirclements. It¬¥s just too much busy work for me to be enjoyable.

üö® ATTENTION ALL GAMERS! üö®

Do you have what it takes to lead your nation to victory? Look no further than Hearts of Iron 4, the ultimate World War II strategy game that will test your skills like never before.

üåç Dive into the depths of history and reshape the world with your strategic genius. From commanding massive armies to making crucial diplomatic decisions, every choice you make will have global consequences. The level of detail is mind-blowing, from the intricacies of military planning to political maneuvering.

üéÆ The gameplay is addictive and engaging, keeping you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. With a plethora of nations to choose from, each with its unique strengths and weaknesses, every playthrough is a fresh challenge. Whether you want to rewrite history as Germany, defend democracy as the United States, or lead the Soviet Union to victory, the possibilities are endless.

üí• Hearts of Iron 4 isn't just a game, it's an immersive experience. The graphics and sound design transport you back in time, adding to the thrill and immersion. The attention to detail is astonishing, making you feel like you're truly in the midst of World War II.

üë• And let's not forget the multiplayer aspect! Team up with friends or engage in heated battles against players from around the world. The competitive multiplayer mode adds an extra layer of excitement and strategy, ensuring endless replayability.

üëç In conclusion, Hearts of Iron 4 is a masterpiece of strategy gaming. With its complex gameplay, historical accuracy, and immersive experience, it surpasses all expectations. So rally your troops, seize the world, and rewrite history. The fate of nations is in your hands!

Great Game! Excellent graphics, and interfaces., with a strong AI. The real  draw back is the  Allies when controlled by the computer will  continuously and endless invade, no mater the loses. This aspect is highly unrealistic   and completely unbalances the game-  you seriously need a a mod of sort that limits the number of invasions especially after high loses. This should be especially true when considering the Politics of  America, or the allies in general. The Only exception being as they Russians were prepared to take massive casualties.So I don't know if the Invasion w/o end is a design flaw for the single player version and overlooked as many play multiplayer, or id it was an international design in order to balance the game. 
 But in  Particular the number of Divisions that are able to be off loaded, in a single region, it s just ridiculous, to see 30 Divines off load on one beachIf you need a reference as to what is even remotely realistic, try looking at the actual D-Day landing, 

The other aspect of the game that is utterly broken id the fact that Switzerland would even think of attacking Germany unprovoked. The Operation tanenbaum, is a neat option, but there is no way that Switzerland would 
 spontaneously join the Allies and attack, it just ridiculous, get rid of it !

My friend really likes HOI4, so I have spent many hours trying to find a way to enjoy it too; but, I have finally concluded that this game is not for me. I spend far too much time watching time pass (and that is at the fastest speed). I do not enjoy micro-managing several hundred divisions along front lines that more closely resemble the Great War - complete with no ability to more said lines without a lengthy wear-down of your enemy but also costing you valuable manpower (the game's most limited resource). My recent attempts to get any achievements have highlighted how much I do NOT enjoy this game with the need to play vanilla games and a new game for almost every achievement. Congratulations to Paradox for encouraging SAM use!

2018 EDIT NOTE
-It should be noted that this review was written during the 2017 controversy in which Paradox  attempted to standerise their DLC prices by raising them across all  international regions. Although they later backed down I still disagree with their DLC policies. I love their games, but untill they make some real change in their business practices I can not in good conscious give this game a possitive recommendation, however I have updated my review for 2018 which you will find at the bottem of this page.

ORIGINAL REVIEW
-I AM GOING ON A FULL PARADOX STRIKE!!!! Their DLC across all of their grand stategy games has always been crazy but now it is just out of control. Death or Dishonor is a "Country Pack"!!! Please!!! What does Death or Dishonor do that Mods have not already!?!?!?!? Like the German offensive into the USSR they may have been destroying our wallets and winning thus far...BUT NO MORE!!!! The winter has come for Paradox and it is time for us as fans to push back!!!!

-Do not get me wrong! I love this game and I adore Paradox as a game developer and that is exactaly why I am being so tough on them. This will destroy them in the end. It is time for us as fans to remeber that we control the market and we have the power to stop this! It is better to stop this now rather than later. RISE UP PARADOX FANS!!!! RISE UP AND SAVE YOUR GAMES!!!

-But really though I am addicted to this game and can not stop playing so does it even matter?

2018 UPDATE
-I suppose it is unfair that I have not given this game a rating like I have in all my other reviews. Furthermore I have not actually reviewed the game, rather, I have written a rather passionate rant against Paradox that when looked at a year later may seem rather odd and nonsensical. As I stated in my 'edit note', my original review was written at a rather tense time that not everyone in the HOI4 community might be aware of. So put into its proper context my original review might begin to make more sense, however I have still failed to give a proper review and express my feelings on the game itself. I will now attempt to correct this.

-The actual gave itself is great. It is more accessible than most grand strategy games and the modding community is one of the best on all of the Steam Workshop. The modding community insures that you will practically never grow bored, even after hundreds of hours. The game itself I would give a 8/10. It has some issues with AI and an overall lack of content, HOWEVER, if you factor in the many amazing mods you will have access to this game easily becomes a 10/10! 

-So yeah, 10/10 would mod again!

High learning curve but rewarding once you get the hang of it, multiplayer can be fun if you don't get too many trolls. DLC is essential to getting the full value of HOI4. 

Edit: I have spent too much time on this game and I love it. DLC's offer fresh alternate history play-throughs and fun opportunities in multiplayer. That being said the Plane/Tank/Ship designer is still confusing. The addition of Military Industrial Organizations and International Market in the "Arms against Tyranny" DLC allows minor nations to be a part of the world war even if they are not actively fighting. "La R√©sistance" made covert interactions between nations a lot more interesting and gamifying, rather than clicking a button a causing a coup for no reason. Overall even though Paradox is known for pumping out lackluster DLC, Hoi4 is a weird exception to the rule.

A deeply flawed game that is impossible to recommend.

The performance is awful, with regular drops to 30 and oftentimes 15fps (!). The engine is struggling, something fierce. Not only is this unacceptable, but it is unplayable because of how bad that feels. No one should be expected to put up with this for hours on end. Past a certain point in the game, it's all slowdowns and stutters, and slowdowns and stutters. All the while, my CPU is never solicitated above 60%, and my GPU never goes above 50%. The game is technically [i]atrocious[/i], and definitely feels like it. It is begging you to drag it behind the barn and put it out of its misery. At least that is how it feels.

Other than that, I just don't find this game very fun, and it is downright boring at time. And I care not to go into details, because it doesn't deserve that I put the time and energy into that. So many things feel arbitrary and just "there" for the sake of being there. Who designed this stuff? Why does an air wing have to be 100 planes of any kind? Why does a focus takes 70 days to research? I mean, why not 65, 75, 80? So many things are like that. Whatever. One thing I liked was [i]the idea[/i] of the focus tree system though, but on the other hand, can we really associate such a system with the concept of strategy? Maybe, maybe not. I guess it is possible, but in the case of HoIIV, I feel like this system is also dragged down by all the badly executed aspects of the game.

Finally, the game is sold incomplete, and the DLCs are numerous and way overpriced (that's the Paradox game "trope", sure, but in the case of HoIIV I find this to be even more true than usual, and therefore worth stating as another element that's making this impossible to recommend). Which is shameless, especially given the state of the base game (not only its technical state, but yes, [i]especially[/i] its technical state as well).

The music is great. As is often the case with Paradox games. I don't know anything about Andreas Waldetoft, except that his soundtracks are superb, and of such high quality that indeed years ago I had to look up who actually was making that stuff. And sure enough, it's often the same composer. Top tier soundtrack, as always.
